== Implementation == [[File:ETS and carbon tax world map.svg|thumb|350px|Carbon emission trading and carbon tax around the world<br /> {{legend|#2ca25f|Emission trading implemented}} {{legend|#addd8e|Emission trading scheduled}} {{legend|#d95f0e|Carbon tax implemented}} {{legend|#fec44f|Carbon tax scheduled}} {{legend|#e8afe2|Emission trading or carbon tax under consideration}}]]
Both energy and carbon taxes have been implemented in responses to commitments under the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]].<ref name=bashmakov/> In most cases where an [[energy tax|energy]] or carbon tax is implemented, the tax is implemented in combination with various forms of exemptions.
=== Africa ===
====Zimbabwe==== Carbon Tax is payable in foreign currency at the rate of US$0.03 (3 cents) per litre of petroleum and diesel products or 5% of cost, insurance and freight value (as defined in the Customs and Excise Act [Chapter 23:02]), whichever is greater.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zimra.co.zw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=32&Itemid=99|title=Carbon Tax - Zimbabwe Revenue Authority (ZIMRA)|website=www.zimra.co.zw}}</ref>
==== South Africa ==== {{Update|inaccurate=yes|section|date=August 2011}} A tax on emissions has been proposed for South Africa. Announced by Finance Minister [[Pravin Gordhan]], the tax will be implemented starting September 1, 2015 on new motor vehicles.<ref name="english.peopledaily.com.cn">{{cite news |title=South Africa gears up for carbon tax |newspaper= CPC News |url= http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7106312.html |date= 2010-06-16 |accessdate=2010-06-16 }}</ref> This tax will apply at the time of sale, and will be related to the amount of CO<sub>2</sub> emitted by the vehicle. 75 South African Rand will be added to the price for every gram of CO<sub>2</sub> per kilometer the vehicle emits over 120 g/km. The tax will apply to passenger cars first and eventually to commercial vehicles.<ref>{{cite web |title= South Africa: Fuel Emissions |publisher=allafrica.com |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201008040502.html |date=2010-08-04 |accessdate=2010-08-04}}</ref> [[Bakkie]]s (pickup trucks) will be taxed because they are often used as passenger vehicles: this has caused an uproar for fear of affecting industry.
David Powels of the National Association of Automobile Manufacturers of South Africa (NAAMSA), opposes this taxation on light commercial vehicles.<ref name="english.peopledaily.com.cn"/> The tax could increase the cost of new vehicles by 2.5% and cause a decrease in total automobile sales: in addition, Powels questions the ability to accurately predict CO<sub>2</sub> emissions based on engine capacity.<ref name="moneywebtax.co.za">{{cite web |last=Powels |first=David |title=What the new CO<sub>2</sub> tax will mean |publisher=Moneyweb Network |url=http://www.moneywebtax.co.za/moneywebtax/view/moneywebtax/en/page259?oid=51312&sn=Detail |date=August 8, 2010 |accessdate=Aug 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501072138/http://www.moneywebtax.co.za/moneywebtax/view/moneywebtax/en/page259?oid=51312&sn=Detail |archivedate=May 1, 2011 |df= }}</ref> NAAMSA acknowledges the ability of carbon taxes to change consumer behavior for the betterment of the environment, but argues that this tax is not transparent enough for consumers because the taxation occurs at the time of automobile production.<ref name="moneywebtax.co.za"/> Powels says the tax is discriminatory because it targets new vehicles, and that the government should focus on introducing "green fuel" to South Africa.<ref name="moneywebtax.co.za"/>
The goal of the carbon tax is to put South Africa on a "sustainable path".<ref name="environment.gov.za">{{cite web |url = http://www.environment.gov.za/HotIssues/2008/LTMS/A%20LTMS%20Scenarios%20for%20SA.pdf |title = Long Term Mitigation Scenarios Strategic Options for South Africa |publisher = Government of South Africa |date = October 2007 |accessdate = August 16, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110504045439/http://www.environment.gov.za/HotIssues/2008/LTMS/A%20LTMS%20Scenarios%20for%20SA.pdf |archivedate = May 4, 2011 |df = }}</ref> South Africa has produced Long Term Mitigation Scenarios (LTMS) to address climate policy issues that consider variables such as technology, investment, and policy (including carbon taxes) and to clarify South Africa's position for potential [[UNFCC]] negotiations.<ref name="environment.gov.za"/>
=== Asia ===
==== China ==== The Chinese Government Ministry of Finance had proposed to introduce a carbon tax from 2012 or 2013, based on carbon dioxide output from hydrocarbon fuel sources such as oil and coal.<ref>{{cite web | last = Jiawei | first = Zhang | title = China ministries propose carbon tax from 2012 -report | publisher = China Daily | date = 11 May 2010 | url = http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2010-05/11/content_9834525.htm | accessdate = 10 July 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = China ministries propose carbon tax from 2012 -report | work = Reuters | publisher = Alibaba News | date = 10 May 2010 | url = http://news.alibaba.com/article/detail/energy/100297064-1-china-ministries-propose-carbon-tax.html | accessdate = 10 July 2011}}</ref> The introduction of a carbon tax in China might affect the internal market, as well as many other laws and regulations of the country, but given the size of Chinese economy also contribute importantly to the mitigation of climate change.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Farah|first1=Paolo Davide|title=China's Role and Contribution in The Global Governance of Climate Change: Institutional Adjustments for Carbon Tax Introduction, Collection and Management in China|journal=Journal of World Energy Law and Business|date=2015|volume=8|issue=6|ssrn=2695612|accessdate=}}</ref>
==== India ==== On July 1, 2010, India introduced a nationwide carbon tax of 50 rupees per tonne ($1.07/t) of coal both produced and imported into India. In a budget speech in 2014, the finance Minister increased the price to 100 rupees per tonne ( $1.60/t at $60.5 conversion)<ref name="lexisnexis.com">{{cite web|last=Dogra|first= Sapna|date= July 3, 2010|title=India sets $1/mt clean coal tax for domestic producers/importers|work= Platts International Coal Report|url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/hottopics/lnacademic/}}</ref> In India coal is used to power more than half of the country's electricity generation.<ref name="businessweek.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-07-01/india-to-raise-535-million-from-carbon-tax-on-coal.html |title=India to Raise $535 Million From Carbon Tax on Coal |first=Natalie Obiko |last=Pearson |work=Bloomberg Businessweek |date=July 1, 2010 |accessdate=May 14, 2011}}</ref>
India's total coal production is estimated to reach 571.87 million tons in the year ending March 2010 and is expected to import around 100 million tons. The carbon tax expects to raise 25 billion rupees ($535 million) for the financial year 2010–2011. According to then Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee, the clean energy tax will help to finance a National Clean Energy Fund (NCEF).<ref name="businessweek.com"/> Industry bodies have not favored the levy and fear that the resultant higher price of coal could trigger inflation.<ref name="lexisnexis.com"/>
While many remain apprehensive, a carbon tax is a step towards helping India meet their voluntary target to reduce the amount of carbon dioxide released per unit of gross domestic product by 25% from 2005 levels by 2020. Environment Minister Jairam Ramesh told reporters in June 2010 that a domestic tax should come before a global carbon tax, and India has imposed one while others debate the issue. With the new government in India under PM Narendra Modi, the carbon tax has been further increased form 100Rs per tonne to 200Rs per tonne in the Budget 2015-16.<ref name="businessweek.com"/><ref>For more information about India's carbon tax and other efforts being taken to mitigate climate change refer to India's [http://www.indiaenvironmentportal.org.in/files/India%20Taking%20on%20Climate%20Change.pdf Climate Change Initiative for 2010]</ref> Currently the carbon tax stands at 400rs per tonne.
==== Japan ==== In October 2012, Japan introduced a Carbon tax with the goal to take action on mitigating dangerous climate change. The government plans to use the revenues generated from this tax to finance clean energy and energy saving projects.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.env.go.jp/en/policy/tax/env-tax.html|title=Japans Ministry of the Environment - Environmental taxation|accessdate= February 1, 2013}}</ref>
In December 2009, nine industry groupings opposed a carbon tax at the opening day of the [[2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP-15 Copenhagen climate conference]] stating, "Japan should not consider a carbon tax as it would damage the economy which is already among the world's most energy efficient." The industry groupings represented the oil, cement, paper, chemical, gas, electric power, auto manufacturing and electronics, and information technology sectors. The sectors state that "the government has neither studied nor explained thoroughly enough why such a carbon tax is needed, how effective and fair it is and how the payments are to be used."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTOE5B609U20091207|title=Japan industry unites against carbon tax|first=Thomson |last=Reuters |publisher=Reuters |date= Dec 7, 2009 |accessdate= August 9, 2010}}</ref>
In 2005, an environmental tax proposed by Japanese authorities was also delayed due to major opposition from the Petroleum Association of Japan (PAJ), other industries and consumers. The delay was "to avoid putting too much economic burden on end-users as they were already paying heavy taxes on hydrocarbon fuels amid high oil prices." The tax that was to be implemented would be 2,400 yen ($20.85 in 2005 dollars) per tonne of carbon dioxide emitted from fuels. Tax on coal would be about 1.58 yen per kilogram and that on gasoline 1.52 yen per litre (4.3 cents per gallon in 2005 dollars). Officials estimated that the tax would generate income of 37 billion yen a year for the government and result in a payment of 2,100 yen per year for an average household.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.planetark.org/dailynewsstory.cfm/newsid/33193/story.htm |title=Japan should introduce Carbon Tax in 2007-Ministry |first=Thomson |last=Reuters |publisher=Planet Ark World Environment News |date= October 27, 2005 |accessdate=August 3, 2010}}</ref>
==== South Korea ==== On August 22, 2008, The Chong Wa Dae, also known as the Blue house – the executive office and official residence of the South Korean head of state, confirmed a list of 40 new administrative strategy agenda, which included substitution of a carbon tax with the current transportation tax.<ref name="Hyun-cheol">{{cite web |last=Hyun-cheol |first= Kim |title=Carbon Tax to Be Introduced in 2010 |work= The Korea Times |date= August 22, 2008 |url= https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2008/11/123_29803.html |accessdate= August 4, 2010}}</ref> Most revenues of the tax amounting to an annual $11 trillion won ($10.4 billion) will be financed toward the "Low Carbon, Green Growth" move, which was announced in President Lee Myung-bak's speech marking the nation's 63rd Liberation day the week before the announcement.<ref name="Hyun-cheol"/> A carbon tax is imposed on emissions of greenhouse gases including carbon dioxide. The direct taxation system is now applied to several European countries, such as Sweden, the Netherlands and Norway, as well as several states in North America. The temporary transportation tax, one of the major objective taxes in the country, is slated to end in 2009. About 80 percent of its yield is used in transportation-related work like road construction. Additional taxation amendment could follow with a "tax on emissions" bottom line, in possible implementations of tax discrimination according to a vehicles' size and a carbon tax on the currently tax-free thermal power plants. Taxation on emissions is inevitable in that low carbon policies take substantial budget, the government says.<ref name="Hyun-cheol"/>
In February 2010, a deputy finance minister Yoon Young-sun confirmed that South Korea is considering a carbon tax to help reduce emissions 4% from 2005 levels by 2020.<ref name="Yoon">{{cite web |url=http://www.businessgreen.com/business-green/news/2258030/south-korea-mulls-carbon-tax |title=South Korea mulls carbon tax |date=February 17, 2010 |publisher=Business Green |accessdate=January 5, 2011}}</ref> This would be in conjunction with a [[Emissions trading|cap-and-trade]] program to be implemented later this year. With a tax rate of 31,828 won (25 Euros) per ton of CO<sub>2</sub>, the South Korean government would collect 9.1 trillion won ($7.9 billion) in tax revenue based on [[List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions|2007 emissions]]. Income from the carbon tax would be used to reduce corporate and income taxes. On July 22, 2010, Chairman Sohn Kyung-shik of the Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry asked for the South Korean government to delay the implementation of the carbon tax: "If the government applies much stricter guidelines over carbon emissions, then companies might be burdened."<ref name="Yoon-mi">{{cite news |url= http://www.koreaherald.com/national/Detail.jsp?newsMLId=20100217000038 |title=Carbon tax plan floated |first=Kim |last=Yoon-mi |newspaper=The Korea Herald |date=March 30, 2010 |accessdate=May 14, 2011}}</ref>
On July 13, 2010, South Korea's government announced plans to more than double its financing for green research and development projects to 3.5 trillion won ($2.9/£1.9bn) by 2013. The finance ministry decided that the new investment will be put into a new dedicated green fund operated by the state-run Korea Finance Corporation, for distribution to private sector projects. The government said that the fund forms part of a huge low-carbon investment drive that will see it invest a total of 107.4 trillion won, or two percent of the country's annual gross domestic product, on green projects between 2009 and 2013.<ref name="Young">{{cite news |last=Young |first=Tom |title=South Korea More than Doubles Green R&D Funding |newspaper=BusinessGreen.com |date= July 13, 2010 |accessdate= 13 August 2010 |url= http://www.businessgreen.com/business-green/news/2258030/south-korea-mulls-carbon-tax }}</ref>
However, the government signaled that in addition to setting aside state funds, it will ask private companies to contribute 2.4 trillion won to the fund. It added that spending from the fund will be directed mainly toward business involved in greenhouse gas emissions reduction and promoting energy efficiency. In addition, the government intends to expand its system of tax breaks to cover new technologies in solar, wind and thermal power, low-emission vehicles, rechargeable batteries and next generation nuclear reactors.<ref name="Young"/>
The government also set a voluntary target last year (2007) to reduce 2020 emissions by four percent on 2005 levels by 2020, and is expected to soon announce plans for carbon trading scheme to begin in 2012.<ref name="Young"/>
==== Taiwan ==== In October 2009, vice finance minister Chang Sheng-ho announced that Taiwan was planning to adopt a carbon tax in 2011.<ref name="Chan, Yvonne">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessgreen.com/business-green/news/2251588/taiwan-plans-taxes-energy-co2|title=Taiwan plans taxes for energy and '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' emissions by 2011|last=Chan|first=Yvonne|date=2009-10-20|publisher=Businessgreen.}}</ref> However, Premier [[Wu Den-yih]] and legislators stated that the carbon taxes would increase public suffering from the recession and that the government should not levy the new taxes until Taiwan's economy has recovered. He opposed the carbon tax.<ref name="View from Taiwan- Archive">{{cite web|url=http://michaelturton.wordpress.com/2009/10/26/environmental-venting/|title=View from Taiwan – Environmental venting|date=2009-10-29|publisher=Michael Turton|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514214451/http://michaelturton.wordpress.com/2009/10/26/environmental-venting/|archivedate=2011-05-14|df=}}</ref> Many Taiwanese citizens are opposed to tax increases as well. However, Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER), the think-tank that was commissioned by the government to advise on its plan to overhaul the nation's taxes, had recommended a levy of NT$2,000 (US$61.8, £37.6) on each tonne of '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' emissions. CIER estimated that Taiwan could raise NT$164.7bn (US$5.1bn, £3.1bn) from the energy tax and a further NT$239bn (US$7.3bn, £4.4bn) from the carbon levy on an annual basis by 2021.<ref name="Chan, Yvonne"/> If Taiwan does pass the carbon tax policy, Taiwan would become the first Asian country with taxation on carbon emissions.<ref>{{cite news |date=2009-10-21 |title=Taiwan: Choosing Carbon Taxes Over Carbon Tariffs |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |author=Max Lin |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/environmentalcapital/2009/10/21/taiwan-choosing-carbon-taxes-over-carbon-tariffs/ |accessdate=2009-10-21}}</ref> Due to the amount of revenues from such a comparatively high carbon tax, the government is planning to subsidize low income families and public transportation by using the revenues from carbon taxes.<ref>{{cite web |date=2009-10-19 |title=Taiwan plans energy tax starting in 2011 |publisher=Earth Times |author=Earth Times Staff |url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/news/290768,taiwan-plans-energy-tax-starting-in-2011.html}}</ref>
=== Oceania ===
==== Australia ==== {{Main|Carbon pricing in Australia}}
On 1 July 2012, the Australian Federal government introduced a [[Carbon pricing in Australia|carbon price]] of [[AUD]]$23 per tonne of emitted [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|CO<sub>2</sub>-e]] on selected fossil fuels consumed by major industrial emitters and government bodies such as councils. To offset the impact of the tax on some sectors of society, the government reduced income tax (by increasing the tax-free threshold) and increased pensions and welfare payments slightly to cover expected price increases, as well as introducing compensation for some affected industries. On 17 July 2014, a report by the [[Australian National University]] estimated that the Australian scheme had cut carbon emissions by as much as 17 million tonnes, the biggest annual reduction in greenhouse gas emissions in 24 years of records in 2013 as the carbon tax helped drive a large drop in pollution from the electricity sector.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Peter|first1=Hannam|title=Carbon price helped curb emissions, ANU study finds|url=https://www.theguardian.com.au/story/2423463/carbon-price-helped-curb-emissions-anu-study-finds/?cs=8|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726141918/http://www.theguardian.com.au/story/2423463/carbon-price-helped-curb-emissions-anu-study-finds/?cs=8|archive-date=2014-07-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
On 17 July 2014, the [[Abbott Government]] passed repeal legislation through the Senate, and Australia became the first nation to abolish a carbon tax.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Lisa|title=Carbon tax is gone: Repeal bills pass the Senate|url=https://www.theguardian.com.au/story/2423819/carbon-tax-is-gone-repeal-bills-pass-the-senate/?cs=8|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726140128/http://www.theguardian.com.au/story/2423819/carbon-tax-is-gone-repeal-bills-pass-the-senate/?cs=8|archive-date=2014-07-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In its place, the government set up the [[Emission Reduction Fund]], paid by taxpayers from consolidated revenue, which according to RepuTex, a markets consultancy, estimated the government's main climate policy may only meet a third of the emissions reduction challenge if Australia is to cut 2000 levels by 5% by 2020.<ref>Sydney Morning Herald, 05/05/2015, [http://www.smh.com.au/environment/climate-change/fall-in-greenhouse-gas-emissions-biggest-in-24-years-20140613-zs7be.html?login_token=e9BZ92STkeChshMYUgug069g0sV661R3WloGQxkTNliYxdfEJ91pcm04WU9yWs6sCKtRYV79U_tefG7Paop8OA1843162&member_token=kUX3or4kwGt0qwyXVBx1IqoNWACq9CuueN61oXgfx-I5y35vBmua3qhoDeLsg0DNqRk2cYraV--SRD16vTaT4Q1843162&expiry=1462433874 Fall in greenhouse gas emissions biggest in 24 years]</ref>
==== New Zealand ==== In 2005, the [[Fifth Labour Government]] proposed a carbon tax in order to meet obligations under the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. The proposal would have set an emissions price of NZ$15 per tonne of CO<sub>2</sub>-equivalent. The planned tax was scheduled to take effect from April 2007, and applied across most economic sectors though with an exemption for [[methane]] emissions from farming and provisions for special exemptions from carbon intensive businesses if they adopted world's-best-practice standards of emissions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.beehive.govt.nz/?q=node/22886 |title=Speech announcing carbon tax detail |first=Pete |last=Hodgson |publisher=Minister of Climate Change Issues, The Beehive, NZ Parliament |date= 4 May 2005 |accessdate= 18 September 2009}}</ref>
After the [[New Zealand general election, 2005|2005 election]], some of the minor parties supporting the [[Fifth Labour Government]] ([[NZ First]] and [[United Future]]) opposed the proposed tax, and it was abandoned in December 2005.<ref>{{cite news|author=NZPA |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=10360930 |title=Carbon tax ditched |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=5 December 2005 |accessdate=24 September 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5k1gJJStW?url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=10360930 |archivedate=24 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2008, the [[New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme]] was enacted via the [[Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2008]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/historic+climate+change+legislation+passes|title=Historic climate change legislation passes|last=Parker|first=David|date=10 September 2008|publisher=New Zealand Government Media Release|accessdate=10 September 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926113104/http://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/historic+climate+change+legislation+passes|archivedate=26 September 2008|df=}}</ref>
=== Europe === In Europe, a number of countries have imposed energy taxes or energy taxes based partly on carbon content.<ref name=bashmakov/> These include Denmark, Finland, Germany, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Slovenia, Sweden, Switzerland, and the UK. None of these countries has been able to introduce a uniform carbon tax for fuels in all sectors. For a review of Europe's experience with carbon taxation see Andersen (2010).<ref>{{cite journal |url= http://sapiens.revues.org/1072 |title=Europe's experience with carbon-energy taxation |first= Prof. Mikael Skou |last=Andersen |journal=SAPIENS |year=2010 |volume=3 |issue=2 |accessdate=2011-08-24}}</ref>
==== European Union ==== During the 1990s, a carbon/energy tax was proposed at the [[European Union|EU]] level but failed due to industrial lobbying.<ref name=pearce>{{cite web |year=2005 |title=The United Kingdom Climate Change Levy: A study in political economy |author=Pearce, D. |publisher=OECD Environment Directorate, [[Centre for Tax Policy and Administration]] |url=http://www.olis.oecd.org/olis/2004doc.nsf/LinkTo/NT00009492/$FILE/JT00179396.PDF |accessdate=August 30, 2009}}</ref> In 2010, the European Commission considered implementing a pan-European minimum tax on pollution permits purchased under the [[European Union Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading Scheme]] (EU ETS) in which the proposed new tax would be calculated in terms of carbon content rather than volume, so that fuels with high energy concentrations, despite their subsequently high carbon content, will no longer carry the same traditionally low price.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/23/business/energy-environment/23carbon.html?ref=cap_and_trade|title=Europe Considers New Taxes to Promote 'Clean' Energy|last=Kanter|first=James|date=2010-06-22|work=The New York Times}}</ref> According to the European Commission, the new plan will charge firms a minimum tax per tonne of carbon dioxide emissions<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/08/787&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en |title=Emissions trading: 2007 verified emissions from EU ETS businesses |date=23 May 2008 |accessdate=22 July 2011 |publisher= The European Commission}}</ref> at a suggested rate of €4 to €30 per tonne of CO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/23/business/energy-environment/23carbon.html?_r=2&ref=cap_and_trade |newspaper=The New York Times |title=Europe Considers New Taxes to Promote 'Clean' Energy |first=James |last=Kanter |date=22 June 2010}}</ref>
==== Denmark ==== As of the year 2002, the standard carbon tax rate since 1996 amounts to 100 [[Danish krone|DKK]] per tonne of CO<sub>2</sub>, equivalent to approximately €13 or US$18. Net carbon emission tax from fuel combustion can vary depending on the level of pollution each source emits, the tax rate varies between 402 DKK per tonne of oil to 5.6 DKK per tonne of natural gas and 0 for non-combustible renewables. The rate for electricity is 1164 DKK per tonne or 10 øre per kWh, equivalent to .013 Euros or .017 US dollars per kWh. The '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' tax applies to all energy users, including the industrial sector. But the industrial companies can be taxed differently according to two principles: the process the energy is used for, and whether or not the company has entered into a voluntary agreement to apply energy efficiency measures. Danish policies like this provide incentives for companies to put in place more sustainable practices similar to a [[cap and trade]] program on carbon dioxide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2000/Denmark_comp02.pdf|title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries: Denmark Review|year=2002|publisher=Head of Publications Service, OECD/IEA 2, rue André-Pascal, 75775 Paris cedex 16, France|author=International Energy Agency|accessdate=2010-08-03}}</ref>
In 1992, Denmark issued a carbon dioxide tax, which was about $14 for business and $7 for households, per ton of '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' . However, Denmark offers a [[tax refund]] for energy efficient changes. One of the main goals for the tax is to have people change their habits, because most of the money collected would be put into research for alternative energy resources.<ref name="Morris,1994">{{cite web |year = 1994 |author = David Morris |title = Green Taxes |publisher = Institute for local self reliance |url = http://www.ilsr.org/ecotax/greentax.html |accessdate = 2010-08-12 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100703095941/http://www.ilsr.org/ecotax/greentax.html |archivedate = 2010-07-03 |df = }}</ref>
==== Finland ==== [[Finland]] was the first country in the 1990s to introduce a CO<sub>2</sub> tax, initially with few exemptions for specific fuels or sectors.<ref>{{cite web |year=2000 |author1=Vourc'h, A. |author2=M. Jimenez |title=Enhancing Environmentally Sustainable Growth in Finland. Economics Department Working Papers No. 229 |publisher=OECD website |url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/21/10/1880843.pdf |accessdate=2010-04-21}}</ref> Since then, however, energy taxation has been changed many times and substantially. These changes were related to the opening of the Nordic electricity market. Other Nordic countries exempted energy-intensive industries, and Finnish industries felt disadvantaged by this. Finland did place a border tax on imported electricity, but this was found to be out of line with EU single market legislation. Changes were then made to the carbon tax to partially exclude energy-intensive firms. This had the effect of increasing the costs of reducing CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (p. 16).
Vourc'h and Jimenez (2000, p. 17) stated that arguments based on competitive losses needed to be viewed with caution. For example, they suggested that carbon tax revenues could be used to reduce labour taxes, which would favour the competitiveness of non energy-intensive industries.
==== France ==== On September 10, 2009, [[France]] detailed a new carbon tax with a new levy on oil, gas and coal consumption by households and businesses that was supposed to come into effect on January 1, 2010. The new carbon tax would be €17 (US$25) per tonne of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) for households and businesses, which will raise the cost of a litre of unleaded fuel by about four euro cents (25 US cents per gallon). The total estimated income from the carbon tax would have been between €3-4.5 billion annually, with 55 percent of profit coming from households and 45 percent coming from businesses.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/24/business/global/24iht-carbon.html?_r=1 |title=France Abandons Plan for Carbon Tax |newspaper=The New York Times |date=2010-03-23 |first=Matthew |last=Saltmarsh |accessdate=2011-01-05 }}</ref> The tax will not apply to electricity as mostly produced by France's network of nuclear reactors.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/sarkozy-unveils-new-french-carbon-tax-20090910-fjhw.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | first=Nadeje | last=Puljak | title=Sarkozy unveils new French carbon tax | date=2009-09-10}}</ref>
On December 30, the bill was blocked by the [[French Constitutional Council]].<ref>{{cite news |first= James |last=Kanter |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/31/business/energy-environment/31carbon.html |title=Council in France Blocks a Carbon Tax as Weak on Polluters |newspaper=The New York Times |date= December 30, 2009}}</ref> It considered the bill included too many exceptions and said they were unconstitutional. It condemned the exemptions for industries as being unequal and inefficient, pointing out that less than half the whole emissions would have been taxed and saying it was unfair to apply the tax only to fuels and heating, which accounted for a limited part of carbon emissions.<ref>[http://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/conseil-constitutionnel/francais/les-decisions/acces-par-date/decisions-depuis-1959/2009/2009-599-dc/decision-n-2009-599-dc-du-29-decembre-2009.46804.html Décision n° 2009-599 DC du 29 décembre 2009] French Constitutional Council {{fr icon}}</ref> Discounts and exceptions would have applied to many aspects of industry and agriculture, including fishing, trucking, and farming.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], despite his vow to "lead the fight to save the human race from global warming",<ref>{{cite news |first=Angelique |last=Chrisafis |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/10/sarkozy-carbon-tax-france |title=Sarkozy Launches Carbon Tax to Help 'Save the Human Race' |newspaper=The Guardian |date= September 10, 2009 |location=London}}</ref> did not support the bill, saying that [[France]] needed support from the rest of the [[European Union]] before it would try and proceed with a carbon tax.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ambrose |last=Evans-Pritchard |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/7507015/France-ditches-carbon-tax-as-social-protests-mount.html |title=France Ditches Carbon Tax as Social Protests Mount |newspaper= The Telegraph |date=March 23, 2010 |location=London}}</ref>
In 2013, a carbon tax was again announced for France. Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault launched the new Climate Energy Contribution (CEC) on September 21, 2013. The tax will apply at a rate of €7/tonne {{CO2}} in 2014, €14.50 in 2015 and rising to €22 in 2016.<ref>[http://www.latribune.fr/journal/edition-du-2309/economie/786332/taxe-carbone-comment-ca-va-marcher.html Taxe carbone : comment ça va marcher], The Tribune 23 September 2013.</ref>
==== Germany ==== The German ecological tax reform was adopted in 1999. After that, the ecological law of the country was amended twice-in 2000 and in 2003. First of all, the law provided rung-by-rung growth of the taxes on fuel and fossil fuels and laid the foundation for the tax for energy. Only in 2003, after the law's gradual implementation, the amount of emissions reduced by 2.4%, which is 20 million tons of {{CO2}}. Thus, the eco-tax is one of the most powerful instruments for climate protection in Germany. The number of workplaces rose by 250,000 jobs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biomassa.de/news-carbon-tax-policy-in-germany-26.html|title=Carbon tax policy in Germany|website=biomassa.de}}</ref>
==== Republic of Ireland ==== In 2004, following a policy review, the [[Irish Government]] rejected the introduction of a carbon tax as a policy option.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=1923|title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Ireland- 2007 Review|year=2007|publisher=International Energy Agency's website|page=154|author=IEA|accessdate=2010-04-21}}</ref> However, in 2007 a [[Fianna Fáil]]-[[Green Party of Ireland|Green Party]] coalition government was formed, and promised to reconsider the matter. In the 2010 budget the country's first carbon tax was introduced.<ref>The 2010 budget was delivered in December 2009</ref> The new tax was levied at €15 per tonne of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insideireland.ie/2009/12/09/archive2313-2373/|title=Carbon tax of €15 a tonne announced|date=2009-12-09|publisher=Inside Ireland|accessdate=2011-05-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328031928/http://insideireland.ie/2009/12/09/archive2313-2373/|archivedate=2012-03-28|df=}}</ref> (approx. US$20 per tonne).<ref>€1 was equal to US$1.32 as of August 2010. See: [http://www.x-rates.com/calculator.html 9 August 2010, Currency Calculator]</ref>
The carbon tax applies to kerosene, marked gas oil, liquid petroleum gas, fuel oil, and natural gas. The Natural Gas Carbon Tax does not apply to electricity because the cost of electricity is already included in pricing under the [[Single Electricity Market]] (SEM). Similarly, natural gas users are exempt from the tax if they can prove they are using the gas to "generate electricity, for chemical reduction, or for electrolytic or metallurgical processes".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bordgaisenergy.ie/help-and-questions/home/gas/carbon-tax/|title=Help & Questions – Home Gas – Carbon Tax|year=2010|publisher=Bord Gáis Energy website|pages=|author=Bord Gáis Energy|accessdate=2010-07-30}}</ref> "A partial relief from the tax is granted for natural gas delivered for use in an installation that is covered by a greenhouse gas emissions permit issued by the [[Environmental Protection Agency]]. The natural gas concerned will be taxed at the minimum rate specified in the EU Energy Tax Directive, which is €0.54 per megawatt hour at gross calorific value."<ref>{{cite web|author=Revenue|title=Guide to Natural Gas Carbon Tax|url=http://www.revenue.ie/en/tax/excise/leaflets/natural-gas-carbon-tax-guide.html|publisher= Revenue: Irish tax and customs|accessdate=2017-01-06}}</ref> Pure biofuels are also exempt.<ref>{{cite news|date=Jan 30, 2010 |author=Harry McGee|title=Producers of biofuels want changes to carbon tax|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0130/1224263435697.html|pages=|publisher= Irish Times|accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref> The Economic and Social Research Institute has estimated the tax will cost between about €2 and €3 a week per household, or about €156 per year:<ref>{{cite news|author=Harry McGee|title=Carbon tax to drive up fuel costs|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/1209/breaking88.html|pages=|publisher= IrishTimes.com|accessdate=2010-08-02|date=2009-12-12}}</ref> a survey from the Central Statistics Office reports that Ireland's average disposable income was almost €48,000 in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|year=2009|author=AOIFE CARR|title=Irish household income up 10% in 2007|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2008/1203/breaking43.html|pages=|publisher= IrishTimes.com|accessdate=2010-08-02}}</ref>
There is concern that the carbon tax may disproportionately affect elderly persons and low-income households. One group, Active Retirement Ireland, proposes that "an extra allowance of €4 per week be made to people in receipt of the State pension for the 30 weeks currently covered by the fuel allowance," they suggest that "home heating oil be added to the categories covered under the Household Benefit Package, which is available to older people in receipt of the State pension".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.westmeathexaminer.ie/news/roundup/articles/2010/07/28/3998819-multy-woman-among-group-arguing-for-aid-for-elderly/|title=Multy woman among group arguing for aid for elderly |newspaper= Westmeath Examiner|date=2010-07-28|accessdate=2010-08-03 }}</ref>
The tax is paid by companies to the Collector General. Fraudulent violation is punishable under section 1078 of the Taxes Consolidation Act 1997, which allows for a jail sentence of up to 5 years or a fine of no more than €126,970. Failure to comply with the tax violates section 73 of the Finance Act of 2010. Payment for the first accounting period was due in July 2010.<ref>{{cite web|year=2010|author=Revenue|title=Guide to Natural Gas Carbon Tax|url=http://www.revenue.ie/en/tax/excise/leaflets/natural-gas-carbon-tax-guide.pdf |pages=|publisher= Revenue: Irish tax and customs|accessdate=2010-08-04}}</ref>
The NGO Irish Rural Link<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishrurallink.ie|title=Irish Rural Link - Naisc Tuaithe na hÉireann|website=www.irishrurallink.ie}}</ref> has noted that according to the Irish Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI) "a carbon tax would weigh more heavily on rural households."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.esri.ie/UserFiles/publications/20080716090749/WP246.pdf |publisher=ESRI Working Paper |title=A Carbon Tax for Ireland |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016151116/http://www.esri.ie/UserFiles/publications/20080716090749/WP246.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-16 |df= }}</ref> Irish Rural Link claim that experience from other countries has shown that carbon taxation will only succeed if it is part of a comprehensive package of measures, which includes reducing some other taxes which does not appear to be the Government's approach.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.irishrurallink.ie/Publications/IRL%20Briefing%2009.01%20Carbon%20Tax%20and%20Rural%20Ireland.pdf |title= Carbon Tax and Rural Ireland |publisher= Irish Rural Link Carbon Tax Briefing Note |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110514200128/http://www.irishrurallink.ie/Publications/IRL%20Briefing%2009.01%20Carbon%20Tax%20and%20Rural%20Ireland.pdf |archivedate= 2011-05-14 |df= }}</ref>
Carbon Tax was introduced in Ireland in the 2010 budget by the Green Party/ Fianna Fáil coalition government at a rate of €15/tonne {{CO2}} which was applied to motor gasoline and diesel and to home heating oil (diesel). Electricity was exempted as electricity generation from fossil fuel power stations was covered under the [[EU ETS]]. Solid fuels including coal and turf were also exempted.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nesc.ie/assets/files/downloads/project_climate%20change/ucd_workshop/ericgargan.pdf | title=Department of Finance briefing on the Irish Carbon Tax}}</ref>
In 2011, the new government coalition of Fine Gael and Labour raised the carbon tax by 33% to €20/tonne. Farmers were granted a tax relief to compensate for this increase.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/business/budget/budget-2012-the-main-points-from-mortgage-relief-to-carbon-tax-26799683.html |title = Budget 2012: The main points ... from mortgage relief to carbon tax |newspaper = The Irish Independent |date = 6 December 2011}}</ref>
==== Netherlands ==== The [[Netherlands]] initiated a carbon tax in 1990. However, in 1992, it was replaced with a 50/50 carbon/energy tax called the Environmental Tax on Fuels, the taxes are assessed partly on carbon content and partly on energy content. The charge was transformed into a tax and became part of general tax revenues. As such, it fell under the administration of the Ministry of Finance. The general fuel tax is collected on all hydrocarbon fuels. Fuels used as raw materials are not subject to the tax. Tax rates are based 50/50 on the energy and carbon contents of fuels. In 1996, The Regulatory Tax on Energy, another 50/50 carbon/energy tax, was also implemented. The Environmental tax and the regulatory tax are 5.16 Dutch guilder, or NLG, (~$3.13) or per tonne of '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' and 27.00 NLG (~16.40) per tonne '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' respectively. Under the general fuel tax, electricity is not taxed, though fuels used to produce electricity are taxable. Energy-intensive industries used to benefit from preferential rates under this tax but the benefit was cancelled in January 1997. Also, since 1997, nuclear power has been taxed under the general fuel tax at the rate of NLG 31.95 per gram of uranium-235.38<ref>http://www.rprogress.org/publications/2001/eurosurvey_2001.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/EE/Epalib/incent.nsf/c484aff385a753cd85256c2c0057ce35/0483a144da8fa434852564f7004f3e68|title="11.1.5.2. Energy/carbon Taxes"|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://climateanswers.info/2010/07/carbon-and-energy-taxes-in-europe/|title=Climate Answers - Stephen Tindale » Blog Archive » Carbon and energy taxes in Europe|date=|publisher=Climateanswers.info|accessdate=2016-08-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813174348/http://climateanswers.info/2010/07/carbon-and-energy-taxes-in-europe/|archive-date=2011-08-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The European Environment Agency put out an Executive Summary stating "Although the 5th Environmental Action Programme of the EU in 1992 recommended the greater use of economic instruments such as environmental taxes, there has been little progress in their use since then at the EU level." However, "at Member State level, there has been a continuing increase in the use of environmental taxes over the last decade, which has accelerated in the last 5–6 year...Countries including the Netherlands and the United Kingdom."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/92-9167-000-6-sum/page002.html|title=Executive Summary|website=European Environment Agency}}</ref>
More recently, in 2007, The Netherlands introduced a Waste Fund that is funded by a carbon-based packaging tax. This tax was both used to finance the national Treasury and to finance the activities to help reach the goals of recycling 65% of used packaging by 2012.<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/environment/waste/prevention/pdf/Netherlands_Factsheet.pdf "Carbon Tax on Packaging (Netherlands)"], June 2009</ref> The organization Nedvang (Nederland van afval naar grondstof or The Netherlands from waste to value), which was set up in 2005, is the organization supporting producers and importers of packaged goods reaching individual company goals under the Dutch packaging decree. This decree was signed in 2005 and states that producers and importers of packaged goods are responsible for the collection and recycling of that waste, and that at least 65% of that waste has to be recycled. Producers and importers can choose to reach the goals on an individual basis or by joining an organization like Nedvang.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pro-e.org/netherlands1.htm|title=General Information Netherlands - PRO Europe|first=Nest Design Letacek|last=development@nestdesign.com|website=www.pro-e.org}}</ref>
The Carbon-Based Tax on Packaging was analyzed on behalf of the Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment and proven to be ineffective.<ref>[http://www.ce.nl/?go=home.downloadPub&id=1091&file=7226_defrapportASC.pdf "CE Delft"], 2010</ref> Therefore, the packaging tax was abolished. Producer responsibility activities for packaging are now financed based on private contracts, that have been declared legally binding.<ref>[http://www.afvalfondsverpakkingen.nl/english/ "Afvalfonds Verpakkingen"], 2014</ref>
==== Sweden ==== {{Tone|section|date=April 2010}}
In January 1991, Sweden enacted a CO<sub>2</sub> tax of 0.25 SEK/kg ($40 per ton at the time, or EUR 27 at current rates) on the use of oil, coal, natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas, petrol, and aviation fuel used in domestic travel. Industrial users paid half the rate (between 1993 and 1997, 25% of the rate), and certain high-energy industries such as commercial horticulture, mining, manufacturing and the pulp and paper industry were fully exempted from these new taxes.
In 1997, the rate was raised to 0.365 SEK/kg ($60 per ton) of CO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.colby.edu/personal/t/thtieten/eco-taxation.htm|title=Can eco-taxation be effective in reducing carbon emissions? |work=Professor [[Tom Tietenberg]]'s research site|publisher= Colby College|last=Gareth W |first=Osborn|accessdate=2011-05-05 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.se/8522/20070917/|title=Carbon taxes raised to tackle climate change|publisher= The Local (Sweden's news in English)|date= 2007-09-17|accessdate=2011-05-05 }}</ref> In 2007, the tax was SEK 930 (EUR 101) per ton of CO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/Sweden2008.pdf|title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Sweden- 2008 Review|year=2008|publisher=International Energy Agency website|page=150|author=IEA|accessdate=2014-12-25}}</ref>
The tax is credited with spurring a significant move from hydrocarbon fuels to biomass. As the [[Swedish Society for Nature Conservation]] climate change expert Emma Lindberg said, "It was the one major reason that steered society towards climate-friendly solutions. It made polluting more expensive and focused people on finding energy-efficient solutions."<ref name="urdeurdeurde">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/apr/29/climatechange.carbonemissions|title=Sweden's carbon-tax solution to climate change puts it top of the green list|first= Gwladys |last=Fouché|newspaper=The Guardian |date=April 29, 2008|location=London}}</ref><ref name="ekonomifakta.se">{{cite web|url=http://www.ekonomifakta.se/en/Facts-and-figures/Economy/Economic-growth/GDP/?from51=1990&to51=2006&columns51=,1,2,3|title=GDP - Gross Domestic Product - Ekonomifakta|last=Carlgren|first=Fredrik|date=2015-10-07|publisher=Ekonomifakta.se|accessdate=2016-08-24}}</ref>
"It increased the use of bioenergy", said University of Lund Professor Thomas Johansson, former director of energy and climate at the UN Development Programme. "It had a major impact in particular on heating. Every city in Sweden uses district heating. Before, coal or oil were used for district heating. Now biomass is used, usually waste from forests and forest industries."
Economic growth appears to be unaffected. Between 1990 and 2006, Sweden's economy grew by 44-46 percent (approx 2,8% annually), depending on source.<ref name="urdeurdeurde" /><ref name="ekonomifakta.se"/>
==== United Kingdom ==== In 1993, the [[United Kingdom|UK]] government introduced the [[Fuel Price Escalator|fuel duty escalator]] (FDE), an environmental tax on retail petroleum products. The tax was explicitly designed to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in the transport sector. Since carbon is in fixed ratio to the quantity of fuel, the FDE roughly approximated a carbon tax. The transport lobby in the UK was extremely critical of the FDE. The FDE, which was the UK's only "real" carbon tax, failed because of the political criticism it provoked, and the automatic increase of the FDE was cancelled in 1999.<ref name=pearce /> Increases in fuel tax have since been discretionary.
The politically damaging [[UK fuel protests|fuel protests]] in 2000 contributed to the government decision to reduce the real rates of fuel tax. At the time, tax and duty represented more than 75% of the total pump price. In money terms, the past increments of the FDE remain in force, but in real terms, increments have been reduced by the rate of inflation. In 2006, tax represented about ⅔ of the pump price.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4672980.stm |title=Why UK petrol prices remain high |publisher=BBC News |last=Wilson |first=Bill |date=2006-02-02}}</ref>
In addition, the UK's [[Climate Change Levy]] was introduced in 2001.
==== Norway ==== Norway introduced a CO<sub>2</sub> tax on hydrocarbon fuels in 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=1580|title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Norway- 2005 Review|year=2005|publisher=International Energy Agency's website|page=208|author=IEA|accessdate=2010-04-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615055008/http://iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=1580|archive-date=2010-06-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The tax started at a high rate of US$51 per tonne of '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' on gasoline, with an average tax of US$21 per tonne<ref>{{cite web |year=2002 |author=Annegrete Bruvoll |author2=Bodil Merethe Larsen |title=Greenhouse gas emissions in Norway Do carbon taxes work? |url=http://www.ssb.no/publikasjoner/DP/pdf/dp337.pdf |page=28 |publisher=Statistics Norway, Research Department |accessdate=2011-09-15}}</ref> The tax was also applied to diesel, mineral oil, oil and gas used in North Sea extraction activities.<ref>{{cite web |year=1998 |author=OECD |title=Economic/Fiscal Instruments: Taxation (i.e., carbon/energy) Annex I Expert Group on the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change |url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/36/50/2392474.pdf |page=94 |publisher=Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development website |accessdate=2010-04-21}}</ref> The International Energy Agency's (IEA) 2001 Review of Norway in the Energy Policies of IEA Countries stated that "since 1991 a carbon dioxide tax has applied in addition to excise taxes on fuel." It is among the highest carbon taxes in the OECD. Carbon taxation is also applied to the production of oil and gas offshore. The IEA estimates for revenue generated by the CO<sub>2</sub> tax in 2004 were 7,808 million NOK<ref name="IEA 2005 204">{{cite web|url=https://www.iea.org/publications/free_new_Desc.asp?PUBS_ID=1580|title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Norway- 2005 Review|year=2005|publisher=International Energy Agency's website|page=204|author=IEA|accessdate=2010-08-04}}</ref> (about US$1.3 billion in 2010 dollars).
According to IEA 2005 Review of Norway,<ref name="IEA 2005 204"/> Norway's CO<sub>2</sub> tax is its most important climate policy instrument, and covers about 64% of Norwegian CO<sub>2</sub> emissions and 52% of total GHG emissions. Some industry sectors have been granted exemptions from the tax to preserve their competitive position. Various studies in the 1990s, and an economic analysis by Statistics Norway, have estimated the effect of the CO<sub>2</sub> tax to be a reduction of 2.5–11% of Norwegian emissions under a business-as-usual approach (i.e., the predicted emissions that would have occurred without the tax). However, even with the carbon tax, Norway's per capita emissions rose by 15% between 1991 (when the carbon tax was introduced) and 2008.<ref name="nrel">{{cite web |author=Sumner, J, Bird, L, & Smith H |title=Carbon Taxes: A Review of Experience and Policy Design Considerations |publisher=National Renewable Energy Laboratory |url=http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy10osti/47312.pdf |accessdate=2011-06-06 | date=December 2009}}</ref>
In attempt to reduce {{CO2}} emissions by a larger amount, Norway implemented the first phase of an Emissions Trading Scheme in 2005<ref name=":0a">{{Cite web|url=https://ieta.wildapricot.org/resources/Resources/Case_Studies_Worlds_Carbon_Markets/norway_case_study_may2015.pdf|title=Norway: An Emissions Trading Case Study|last=|first=|date=May 2015|website=International Emissions Trading Association|publisher=International Emissions Trading Association|access-date=14 November 2016}}</ref> and joined the European Union Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) in 2008.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldbank.org/content/dam/Worldbank/document/Climate/background-note_carbon-tax.pdf|title=Putting a Price on Carbon With A Tax|last=|first=|date=|website=World Bank|publisher=World Bank|access-date=14 November 2016}}</ref> As of 2013, roughly 55% of {{CO2}} emissions in Norway are taxed and emissions that are not covered by a carbon tax are included in the EU ETS.<ref name=":1" /> Certain {{CO2}} taxes are applied to emissions that result from petroleum activities on the continental shelf.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/policiesandmeasures/pams/norway/name-23847-en.php|title=IEA - Norway|website=www.iea.org|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> This tax is charged per liter of oil and natural gas liquids produced, as well as per [[standard cubic meter]] of gas burnt off or otherwise directly emitted into the air.<ref name=":2" /> However, this carbon tax is considered a deductible operating cost for petroleum production which can therefore be written off to reduce the ordinary taxes paid by oil companies.<ref name=":2" /> In 2013, carbon tax rates were doubled in Norway to a rate of 0.96 NOK per liter/standard cubic meter of mineral oil and natural gas.<ref name=":2" /> As of 2016, the tax rate has been increased to 1,02 NOK per liter or standard cubic meter of oil and natural gas.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.norskpetroleum.no/en/economy/governments-revenues/|title=The government's revenues - Norwegianpetroleum.no - Norwegian Petroleum|newspaper=Norwegian Petroleum|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> Despite this increase, there is intention to reduce the tax in the future if there is a rise in the EU ETS price from the rate it was when the increased carbon tax rate was implemented.<ref name=":0a" /> According to the Norwegian Ministry of the Environment, {{CO2}} taxes have been the most important tool for reducing emissions produced by petroleum activities and there is a low level of {{CO2}} emissions per produced oil equivalent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.regjeringen.no/globalassets/upload/MD/Vedlegg/Rapporter/T-1482E.pdf|title=Norway`s Fifth National Communication under the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Status report as of December 2009|last=|first=|date=December 2009|website=Norwegian Ministry of the Environment|publisher=Norwegian Ministry of the Environment|access-date=14 November 2016}}</ref>
==== Switzerland ==== In January 2008, [[Switzerland]] implemented a CO<sub>2</sub> [[Steering tax|incentive tax]] on all hydrocarbon fuels, such as coal, oil and natural gas, unless they are used for energy. Gasoline and diesel fuels are not affected by the CO<sub>2</sub> tax. The tax is collected by the Swiss Federal Customs Administration. It is an incentive tax because it is designed to promote the economic use of hydrocarbon fuels.<ref>{{cite web |year = 2010 |author = [[Federal Office for the Environment]] |title = CO<sub>2</sub> tax |url = http://www.bafu.admin.ch/co2-abgabe/index.html?lang=de |page = 1 |publisher = Agency for the Environment FOEN |accessdate = 2010-08-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100826044637/http://www.bafu.admin.ch/co2-abgabe/index.html?lang=de |archivedate = 2010-08-26 |df = }}</ref> The tax amounts to [[Swiss franc|CHF]] 12 per tonne CO<sub>2</sub> (US $11.41 per tonne CO<sub>2</sub>), which is the equivalent of CHF 0.03 per litre of heating oil (US $0.108 per gallon) and CHF 0.025 per m<sup>3</sup> of natural gas (US $0.024 per m<sup>3</sup>).<ref name="IEA 2008 1">{{cite web|year=2008 |author=IEA |title=CO<sub>2</sub> Tax on Stationary Fuels |url=http://www.iea.org/textbase/pm/?mode=cc&id=3979&action=detail |page=1 |publisher=International Energy Agency's website |accessdate=2010-08-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501105005/http://www.iea.org/textbase/pm/?mode=cc&id=3979&action=detail |archivedate=May 1, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="1 Swiss franc = 0.9499 US dollar">{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&q=convert+CHF+to+dollars|title=convert CHF to dollars - Google Search|website=www.google.com}}</ref> This tax comes from Switzerland's 1999 Federal Law on the Reduction of CO<sub>2</sub> (CO<sub>2</sub> Law). Although Switzerland prefers to rely on voluntary actions and measures to achieve emissions reductions, the CO<sub>2</sub> Law mandated the introduction of a CO<sub>2</sub> tax if voluntary measures proved to be insufficient.<ref>{{cite web |year=2000 |author=IEA |title=Implementation of the Law on the Reduction of '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' Emissions (CO<sub>2</sub> Law) |url=http://www.iea.org/textbase/pm/?mode=cc&action=detail&id=514 |page=1 |publisher=International Energy Agency's website |accessdate=2010-08-04}}</ref> In 2005, the federal government decided that additional measures were needed to achieve emissions reductions and meet [[Kyoto Protocol]] commitments of an 8% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions below 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012.<ref name="IEA 2007 128">{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2007/switzerland2007.pdf|title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Switzerland|year=2007|publisher=International Energy Agency's website|page=128|author=IEA|accessdate=2010-08-04}}</ref> In 2007, the CO<sub>2</sub> tax was approved by the [[Swiss Federal Council]], coming into effect 2008.<ref name="IEA 2008 1"/> In 2010, the highest tax rate will be CHF 36 per tonne of CO<sub>2</sub> (US $34.20 per tonne CO<sub>2</sub>).<ref name="Agency for the Environment FOEN 2010 1">{{cite web |year = 2010 |author = Agency for the Environment FOEN |title = Redistribution of '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' tax |url = http://www.bafu.admin.ch/co2-abgabe/05179/05316/index.html?lang=de |page = 1 |publisher = Agency for the Environment FOE |accessdate = 2010-08-09 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110501152941/http://www.bafu.admin.ch/co2-abgabe/05179/05316/index.html?lang=de |archivedate = 2011-05-01 |df = }}</ref><ref name="google.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&q=convert+CHF+to+dollars|title=convert CHF to dollars - Google Search|website=www.google.com}}</ref>
Companies are allowed to exempt themselves from the tax by participating in a Swiss [[cap-and-trade]] emissions trading scheme where they voluntarily commit to legally binding targets to reduce their CO<sub>2</sub> emissions.<ref>{{cite web |year = 2008 |author = European Parliament |title = Options and Implications of Linking the EU ETS with other Emissions Trading Schemes |url = http://www.europarl.europa.eu/activities/committees/studies/download.do?file=19802 |page = 30 |publisher = European Parliament |accessdate = 2010-08-04 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Under this scheme, emission allowances are given to companies for free, and each year emission allowances equal to the amount of CO<sub>2</sub> emitted must be surrendered by the company. Companies are allowed to sell or trade excess permits. However, should a company fail to surrender the correct amount of allowances, they must pay the CO<sub>2</sub> tax retroactively for each tonne of CO<sub>2</sub> emitted since the exemption was granted.<ref name="IEA 2007 128"/> About 400 companies take part in trading CO<sub>2</sub> emission credits under this program. In 2009, for the second year in a row, the companies returned enough credits to the Swiss government to cover their CO<sub>2</sub> emissions for the year. The 2009 report shows that companies emitted only about 2.6 million tonnes of CO<sub>2</sub>, falling well below the total permissible quantity of 3.1 million tonnes.<ref>{{cite web |year=2010 |author=Agency for the Environment FOEN |title=Companies exceed '''CO<sub>2</sub>''' targets in 2009 |url=http://www.bafu.admin.ch/dokumentation/medieninformation/00962/index.html?lang=de&msg-id=34175 |page=1 |publisher=Federal Office for Environment |accessdate=2010-08-09}}</ref> The Swiss carbon market still remains fairly small, with few emissions permits being traded. Swiss domestic law tends to favor the use of a CO<sub>2</sub> tax to achieve emissions reductions and this preference for taxes combined with an immature carbon market could partially explain why Switzerland has not yet joined the [[European Union Emission Trading Scheme]] (EU ETS).<ref>{{cite web |year = 2009 |author = Giles Broom |title = Swiss Favour Carbon Tax Over Emissions Trading |url = http://www.swisster.ch/news/business/swiss-favour-carbon-tax-over-emissions-trading.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091209112002/http://www.swisster.ch/news/business/swiss-favour-carbon-tax-over-emissions-trading.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2009-12-09 |page = 1 |publisher = Swisster |accessdate = 2010-08-04 }}</ref>
The tax is revenue neutral, and its revenues are redistributed proportionally to companies and to the Swiss population. For example, if the population bears 60% of the tax burden, they will receive 60% of the redistribution. For companies, revenues will be redistributed to all companies, except those who chose to exempt themselves from the tax through the cap-and-trade program.<ref name="Agency for the Environment FOEN 2010 1"/> The revenue is given to the companies in proportion to the total payroll of their employees and is distributed through an AHV compensation fund (Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance) that pays the relevant amount of revenue to the company.<ref name="bafu.admin.ch">{{cite web |year=2010 |author=Agency for the Environment FOEN |title=Redistribution of the CO<sub>2</sub> tax: The economy receives some 360 million francs |url=http://www.bafu.admin.ch/dokumentation/medieninformation/00962/index.html?lang=de&msg-id=33713 |page=1 |publisher=Federal Office for Environment |accessdate=2010-08-09}}</ref> The revenues from the tax that were paid by the Swiss population are redistributed equally to all Swiss residents through health insurance companies and a deduction on their insurance premium.<ref name="Agency for the Environment FOEN 2010 1"/><ref name="bafu.admin.ch"/> In June 2009, the Swiss Parliament decided to allocate about one-third of the revenue from the carbon tax to a 10-year building program for climate-friendly building renovations. This program promotes building renovations, the use of renewable energies, the utilization of waste heat, and building engineering.<ref name="Agency for the Environment FOEN 2010 1"/>
As part of the early-redistribution program decided by the Swiss Federal Council in 2009, the tax revenue from 2008, 2009, and 2010, are being distributed in 2010.<ref name="Agency for the Environment FOEN 2010 1"/> In 2008 alone, the tax of CHF 12 per tonne of CO<sub>2</sub> raised around CHF 220 million (US $209 million) in revenue.<ref name="google.com"/> As of June 16, 2010, a total of around CHF 360 million (US $342 million) have become available for distribution to the Swiss population and economy.<ref name="google.com"/><ref name="bafu.admin.ch"/> It is estimated that in 2010, at the highest tax rate of CHF 36 per tonne of CO<sub>2</sub>, the revenue from the tax will be about CHF 630 million (US $598 million).<ref name="google.com"/> Out of the projected CHF 630 million, CHF 200 million (US $190 million) will be allocated for the building program and the remaining CHF 430 million (US $409 million) will be redistributed in 2010 to the population and the economy.<ref name="Agency for the Environment FOEN 2010 1"/><ref name="google.com"/> The [[International Energy Agency]] (IEA) commends Switzerland's CO<sub>2</sub> tax for its excellent design and notes that the recycling of the tax revenues to all citizens and enterprises is "sound fiscal practice".<ref name="IEA 2007 128"/>
Since 2005, transport fuels in Switzerland have been subjected to the Climate Cent Initiative surcharge—a surcharge of CHF 0.015 per litre on gasoline and diesel (US $.0038 per gallon) which will remain in place until the end of 2012.<ref name="1 Swiss franc = 0.9499 US dollar"/> However, this surcharge can be supplemented with a CO<sub>2</sub> tax on transport fuels if emissions reductions are not satisfactory. In their 2007 review, the IEA recommended that Switzerland implement a CO<sub>2</sub> tax on transport fuels or increase the Climate Cent surcharge to better balance the high costs of meeting emissions reductions targets across sectors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2007/switzerland2007.pdf|title=Energy Policies of IEA Countries – Switzerland|year=2007|publisher=International Energy Agency|page=128|author=IEA|accessdate=2010-08-04}}</ref>
Switzerland is currently on track to meet its Kyoto Protocol commitment of an 8% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions below 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012. The combination of the CO<sub>2</sub> tax and other voluntary measures by businesses and private individuals is enabling Switzerland to achieve these reduction goals.<ref>{{cite web |year=2009 |author=Agency for the Environment FOEN |title=Switzerland Able to Meet its International Commitments |url=http://www.bafu.admin.ch/dokumentation/medieninformation/00962/index.html?lang=en&msg-id=30656 |page=1 |publisher=Federal Office for the Environment |accessdate=2010-08-11}}</ref>
=== Central America ===
==== Costa Rica ==== {{Clear}} In 1997, [[Costa Rica]] imposed a 3.5 percent carbon tax on hydrocarbon fuels.<ref>{{cite web|last= Meyer|first= Peter|title= United States. Costa Rica: Background and U.S. Relations|year= 2010|url= http://assets.opencrs.com/rpts/R40593_20100222.pdf|format= PDF|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110807121815/http://assets.opencrs.com/rpts/R40593_20100222.pdf|archivedate= 2011-08-07|df= }}</ref> A portion of the funds generated by the tax go to "Payment for Environmental Services" (PSA) program which gives incentives to property owners to practice sustainable development and forest conservation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Costa Rica: Experts warn about the dangers of missing environmental targets|work= [[Agence France Presse]]|date= October 8, 2009|format=PDF}}</ref> Approximately 11% of Costa Rica's national territory is protected by the plan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://assets.opencrs.com/rpts/R40593_20100222.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807121815/http://assets.opencrs.com/rpts/R40593_20100222.pdf |archivedate=2011-08-07 |df= }}</ref> The program now pays out roughly $15 million a year to around 8,000 property owners.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2438974220070526 | work=Reuters | title=Costa Rica aims to win "carbon neutral" race | date=2007-05-24}}</ref>
=== North America ===
==== Canada ====
In the [[Canadian federal election, 2008|2008 Canadian federal election]], a carbon tax proposed by [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]] leader [[Stéphane Dion]], known as the Green Shift, became a central issue in the campaign. It would have been revenue-neutral, with increased taxation on carbon being balanced by tax cuts for individual citizens. However, it proved to be unpopular and contributed to the defeat of Liberal Party with its worst share of the popular vote since [[Canadian federal election, 1867|Confederation]].<ref>Bryden, Joan. [https://www.thestar.com/News/Canada/article/520836 Liberals cast themselves in leader's light]. ''Toronto Star''. October 20, 2008.</ref><ref>Bilton, Chris. [http://www.eyeweekly.com/blog/post/49116 Green shifting right?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501072424/http://www.eyeweekly.com/blog/post/49116 |date=2011-05-01 }} ''[[Eye Weekly]]''. January 7, 2009</ref><ref>Reid, Scott. [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081224.WStrategists1225/BNStory/politics The good, the (mostly) bad, and the faint signs of hope].
