January 19, 2009.</ref> By contrast, the Conservative party, who won the election, had promised to "develop and implement a North American-wide [[cap-and-trade]] system for greenhouse gases and air pollution, with implementation to occur between 2012 and 2015."<ref>{{cite web|title=Case of the Conservatives’ carbon amnesia|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/case-of-the-conservatives-carbon-amnesia/article4557581/|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]}}</ref>
In 2018, Canada passed the Greenhouse Gas Pollution Pricing Act implementing revenue-neutral carbon tax starting in 2019.<ref>[https://www.canlii.org/en/ca/laws/stat/sc-2018-c-12-s-186/139160/sc-2018-c-12-s-186.html Greenhouse Gas Pollution Pricing Act], in force since 21 June 2018 (page visited on 26 October 2018).</ref><ref name=Nuccitelli>Dana Nuccitelli, [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2018/oct/26/canada-passed-a-carbon-tax-that-will-give-most-canadians-more-money "Canada passed a carbon tax that will give most Canadians more money"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 26 October 2018 (page visited on 26 October 2018).</ref> This fulfils a campaign pledge that [[Justin Trudeau]] made in 2015, before being elected as [[Prime Minister of Canada]].<ref name=Nuccitelli/> The Greenhouse Gas Pollution Pricing Act will apply only to [[Provinces and territories of Canada|provinces]] which do not have provincial carbon pricing systems meeting the federal requirements.<ref name=Nuccitelli/> In each province, the taxed money will be redistributed to citizens ([[household]]s).<ref name=Nuccitelli/>
Canada as a country absorbs more carbon than it emits. This is due to its large land mass (through Photosynthesis, calcium carbonate fixation). Canada produces about 1.5% of the world's emissions and is responsible for absorbing about 12% of the world's total emissions. The group "Scientists Against Climate Change" feels that only by tariffs/taxes on the polluting countries will planetary change be enacted.
===== Quebec ===== {{main|Quebec carbon tax}}
The [[Canadian province]] of [[Quebec]] became the first in Canada to introduce a carbon tax.<ref name="Quebec to collect nation's 1st carbon tax">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2007/06/07/carbon-tax.html,|title=Quebec to collect nation's 1st carbon tax|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="Quebec government to implement carbon tax">{{cite web|url=http://www.torys.com/Publications/Documents/Publication%20PDFs/CCB2007-6.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812123242/http://www.torys.com/Publications/Documents/Publication%20PDFs/CCB2007-6.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-08-12|title=Quebec Government to Implement Carbon Tax|publisher=}}</ref> The tax was to be imposed on energy producers starting October 1, 2007, with revenue collected used for energy-efficiency programs including public transit. The tax rate for gasoline is $CDN0.008 per liter, or about '''$3.50 per tonne''' of {{chem|CO|2}} equivalent.<ref name="Where Carbon is Taxed">{{cite web|url=http://www.carbontax.org/progress/where-carbon-is-taxed/,|title=Where Carbon is Taxed|publisher=}}</ref>
===== British Columbia ===== {{main|British Columbia carbon tax}}
On February 19, 2008, the province of [[British Columbia]] announced its intention to implement a carbon tax of $10 per tonne of [[Carbon dioxide equivalent]] (CO<sub>2</sub>e) emissions (2.41 cents per litre on gasoline) beginning July 1, 2008, making BC the first North American jurisdiction to implement such a tax. The tax will increase each year after until 2012, reaching a final price of '''$30 per tonne''' (7.2 cents per litre at the pumps).<ref name="B.C introduces carbon tax">{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=ecea1487-507c-43ef-ab88-5a972898e0b7&k=38130, |title=B.C. introduces carbon tax |publisher=CanWest MediaWorks Publications |date=22 February 2008 |accessdate=9 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110121155/http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=ecea1487-507c-43ef-ab88-5a972898e0b7&k=38130%2C |archivedate=10 November 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref name="B.C carbon tax notice">{{cite web |url=http://www.rev.gov.bc.ca/documents_library/notices/British_Columbia_Carbon_Tax.pdf |title=British Columbia Carbon Tax |date=February 2008 |publisher=Ministry of Small Business and Revenue |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513055926/http://www.rev.gov.bc.ca/documents_library/notices/British_Columbia_Carbon_Tax.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-13 |df= }}</ref> Unlike previous proposals, legislation will keep the pending carbon tax revenue neutral by reducing corporate and income taxes at an equivalent rate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bcbudget.gov.bc.ca/2008/backgrounders/backgrounder_carbon_tax.htm |title=B.C.'s Revenue-neutral Carbon Tax |work= Balanced Budget 2008 Backgrounder |publisher=Province of British Columbia |date=1 July 2008 |accessdate=5 May 2011 }}</ref> Also, the government will also reduce taxes above and beyond the carbon tax offset by $481 million over three years.<ref name="B.C introduces carbon tax"/> In January 2010, the carbon tax was applied to biodiesel. Before the tax actually went into effect, the government of British Columbia sent out "rebate cheques" from expected revenues to all residents of British Columbia as of December 31, 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://bc.ctvnews.ca/b-c-tax-rebate-cheques-due-out-this-week-1.304162 |title=B.C. tax rebate cheques due out this week |author=CTV News |work=CTV British Columbia News |date=23 June 2008 |accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> In January 2013, the carbon tax was collecting about $1 billion each year which was used to lower other taxes in British Columbia. [[Terry Lake]], the minister of the environment of British Columbia, said ''"It makes sense, it's simple, it's well accepted."''<ref>{{cite web |url = http://earthfix.opb.org/energy/article/taxing-carbon-to-pay-for-transportation-infrastruc/ |title = Talk Of A Carbon Tax In The Northwest |first = Ashley |last = Ahearn |work = EarthFix · Oregon Public Broadcasting |date = 7 January 2013 |quote = "It makes sense, it's simple, it's well accepted," says Terry Lake, the minister of the environment of British Columbia. |accessdate = 9 January 2013 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130116130518/http://earthfix.opb.org/energy/article/taxing-carbon-to-pay-for-transportation-infrastruc/ |archive-date = 2013-01-16 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
The British Columbia revenue-neutral carbon tax is based on the following principles: * '''All carbon tax revenue is recycled through tax reductions''' – The government has a legal requirement to present an annual plan to the legislature demonstrating how all of the carbon tax revenue will be returned to taxpayers through tax reductions. The money will not be used to fund government programs.<ref name=p>{{cite web|title=What is a Carbon Tax?|url=http://www.fin.gov.bc.ca/tbs/tp/climate/A1.htm|website=Government of British Columbia|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref> * '''The tax rate started low and increases gradually''' – Starting at a low rate gave individuals and businesses time to make adjustments and respects decisions made prior to the announcement of the tax.<ref name=p /> * '''Low-income individuals and families are protected''' – A refundable Low Income Climate Action Tax Credit is designed to help offset the carbon tax paid by low-income individuals and families.<ref name=p /> * '''The tax has the broadest possible base''' – Virtually all emissions from fuel combustion in B.C. captured in Environment Canada's National Inventory Report are taxed, with no exemptions except those required for integration with other climate action policies in the future and for efficient administration.<ref name=p /> * '''The tax will be integrated with other measures''' – The carbon tax will not, on its own, meet B.C.'s emission-reduction targets, but it is a key element in the strategy. The carbon tax and complementary measures such as a "cap and trade" system will be integrated as these other measures are designed and implemented.<ref name=p />
Following implementation many Canadians concluded that the carbon tax generally benefitted the [[British Columbia#Economy|British Columbian economy]], in large part because its revenue neutral feature did indeed reduce personal income taxes.<ref>{{cite news | last = Beaty | first = Ross | last2 = Lipsey | first2 = Richard | last3 = Elgie | first3 = Stewart | title = The shocking truth about B.C.'s carbon tax: It works | newspaper = The Globe and Mail | location = Toronto, Ontario | date = 9 July 2014 | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-debate/the-insidious-truth-about-bcs-carbon-tax-it-works/article19512237/ | access-date = 10 December 2015}}</ref> However some industries complained loudly that the tax had harmed them, notably cement manufacturers and farmers.<ref>{{cite news | title = British Columbia's carbon tax; The evidence mounts | newspaper = The Economist | date = 31 July 2014 | url = https://www.economist.com/blogs/americasview/2014/07/british-columbias-carbon-tax | access-date = 10 December 2015}}</ref> Nevertheless, the tax generated sufficient praise to attract broad attention in the United States and elsewhere from those seeking an economically efficient way of reducing the emission of greenhouse gases without hurting [[economic growth]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Halstead | first = Ted | title = The Republican Solution for Climate Change; Republicans have the ability to offer a market-based solution to climate change, so why aren’t they doing it? | newspaper = The Atlantic | location = Washington, D.C. | date = 16 November 2015 | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/11/a-conservative-approach-to-addressing-climate-change/415887/ | access-date = 10 December 2015}}</ref>
===== Alberta =====
In July 2007, [[Alberta]] enacted the Specified Gas Emitters Regulation, Alta. Reg. 139/2007,<ref>{{cite web|title=Specified Gas Emitters Regulation, Alta Reg 139/2007|url=http://canlii.ca/t/jg43|accessdate=11 December 2013}}</ref> (SGER). This carbon tax<ref>{{cite news|title=Alberta's carbon-tax windfall dilemma|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/energy-and-resources/albertas-carbon-tax-windfall-dilemma/article10959863/|accessdate=12 December 2013|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=9 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Tax Favored By Most Economists|url=http://www.brookings.edu/research/opinions/2013/03/12-taxing-carbon-gale|publisher=Brookings|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref> requires a $15/tonne contribution be made to the "Climate Change and Emissions Management Fund" (CCEMF) by companies that emit more than 100,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas annually to either reduce their CO<sub>2</sub> emissions per barrel by 12 percent, or buy an offset in Alberta to apply against their total emissions.<ref name="To Spur Innovation, What Price to Put on Oil Sands Carbon?">{{cite web|url=http://www.tyeesolutions.org/?p=1204,|title=To Spur Innovation, What Price to Put on Oil Sands Carbon? - Tyee Solutions Society|website=www.tyeesolutions.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=January 8, 2008|title=Carbon tax proposal a non-starter in Alberta|work= [[CBC News]]|accessdate=August 19, 2010 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2008/01/08/renner-carbon.html}}</ref><ref name="canada.com">{{cite web|date=March 9, 2007|title=Go figure – a carbon tax crafted right here at home|work=[[The Calgary Herald]]|accessdate=August 19, 2010|url=http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/columnists/story.html?id=8c3c9760-7cbe-4fab-b00c-1c77243903b6|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511122351/http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/columnists/story.html?id=8c3c9760-7cbe-4fab-b00c-1c77243903b6|archivedate=May 11, 2011|df=}}</ref> In January 2016, the contribution required by large emitters to the CCEMF was increased by the provincial government to $20/tonne.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/news/energy/alberta-boosts-carbon-tax-to-20-a-tonne-starting-in-2016-as-part-of-climate-change-plan|title=Alberta boosts carbon tax to $20 a tonne starting in 2016 as part of climate change plan|date=25 June 2015|publisher=}}</ref> The tax will fall most heavily on oil companies and coal-fired electricity plants. It intends to give companies a real incentive to lower emissions while fostering technology that makes the job easier. The plan only covers the largest companies that produce 70% of Alberta's emissions.<ref name="canada.com"/> There are concerns that this is a serious omission because the smallest energy producers are often the most casual about emissions and pollution.<ref name="canada.com"/> The carbon tax is currently $20 per tonne.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alberta Extends Climate Change Rules, Including $15 Tonne Carbon Levy|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/12/19/alberta-climate-change_n_6357480.html|website=Huffpost Alberta|accessdate=27 November 2015}}</ref> Because Alberta has the highest greenhouse gas emissions in Canada the majority of Albertans are strongly opposed to a nationwide carbon tax. There is a fear that a nationwide carbon tax would cause Alberta's economy to suffer significantly more in proportion to other provinces. Alberta is also opposed to a Cap and Trade system it fears the trades will pull revenue out of the province, a fear not to be dismissed. Alberta's local carbon price allows the money to stay within Alberta.<ref>{{cite news|last=Simpson|first= Jeffery|date= January 22, 2010|title=Many Albertans agree: A carbon tax was the best solution|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate= August 19, 2010 |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/many-albertans-agree-a-carbon-tax-was-the-best-solution/article1441309/}}</ref>
On November 23, 2015, the Alberta government announced a new carbon tax scheme very similar to British Columbia's in that it will be applied to the entire economy. All businesses and residents will pay a carbon tax based upon the carbon dioxide equivalent emissions, including the burning of wood and biofuels. The tax will come into force in 2017 with a price of $20 per tonne. The price will increase to $30 per tonne in 2018 and increase thereafter by the rate of inflation plus 2%.
Also announced will be the reduction of coal-powered electricity generation. Currently, coal provides 51% of the power in the province. The target is to eliminate coal generation by 2030. Renewable energy production (primarily wind and solar in Alberta) is targeted at 30% of generating capacity by 2030.
The effect on consumers will be an increase of 6.73¢ per litre for gasoline and $1.517 per gigajoule for natural gas.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Government of Alberta|title=Carbon levy and rebates|url=https://www.alberta.ca/climate-carbon-pricing.aspx|website=www.alberta.ca|accessdate=21 January 2018}}</ref> Because it is primarily generated from burning hydrocarbons, electricity prices are also expected to rise, although the exact amount is currently unknown. The total personal cost is estimated to be about $120 per capita, based on a $300 per household cost. Rebates will be provided to low income earners and temporary rebates provided to exporters to offset competitive disadvantages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macleans.ca/economy/economicanalysis/heres-what-we-know-and-dont-know-about-albertas-carbon-tax/|title=Here's what we know—and don’t know—about Alberta's carbon tax|website=Macleans|last1=Tombe|first1=Trevor|accessdate=27 November 2015}}</ref>
==== United States ==== [[File:Estimated Effect of Carbon Tax in US.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Estimated effect of a carbon tax on sources of United States electrical generation (US Energy Information Administration)]] According to the Carbon Tax Center,<ref name="carbontax.org">{{Cite web|url=https://www.carbontax.org/where-carbon-is-taxed/|title=Where Carbon Is Taxed|website=www.carbontax.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-22}}</ref> the United States is one of the few large and industrialized nations on Earth that does not implement a Carbon tax. One simple solution being considered is to implement a federal carbon emissions tax, instead of relying on states to enforce their own. According to economists a tax would be the simplest and the easiest way to reduce emissions since, primarily, it seems like a plan both parties can get behind since it would not impose strict regulations on business, instead allowing the industries to self regulate, while also a showing that the government is taking steps to protect the environment. Furthermore, a tax would lead both producers and consumers to adjust their respective habits accordingly, and in ways that may become more efficient.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/06/28/the-myriad-benefits-of-a-carbon-tax/?_r=0|title=The Myriad Benefits of a Carbon Tax|last=Tyson|first=Laura D'Andrea|newspaper=Economix Blog|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en}}</ref> On July 23, 2018 Congressman Carlos Curbelo (R-FL) introduced H.R. 6463, <ref>H.R. 6463 https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/6463</ref> the "Modernizing America with Rebuilding to Kick-start the Economy of the Twenty-first Century with a Historic Infrastructure-Centered Expansion (MARKET CHOICE) Act." There is also a national movement called [[Citizens' Climate Lobby]] to create support across parties to put a national price on Carbon.
'''Internal price on carbon'''
Although the United States does not currently implement a carbon tax, many American corporations have set the precedent on setting an “internal price on carbon”. Companies calculate this internal price to assess the risk value of future projects when making economic investment decisions. Companies usually assess a higher internal price when i) the company emits large amounts of {{CO2}}, and ii) when the company projects further into the future.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21591601-some-firms-are-preparing-carbon-price-would-make-big-difference-carbon-copy|title=Carbon copy|website=The Economist|access-date=2017-05-01}}</ref> Oil companies usually have assets (factories, refineries) that have a long lifespan and that can be affected by energy policies in the future; the products and assets of consumer-goods companies are mostly influenced by current policies, so their carbon prices are usually lower.
Oil companies like Shell and ConocoPhillips apply this carbon price to current and future operations; the motivation is to "apply the carbon price as much to spur mitigation as to quantify risks". {| class="wikitable" |+Internal carbon prices for various US companies !Company !Internal carbon price (US$) !CO<sub>2</sub> emitted in 2013 (million tonnes) |- |Exxon Mobil |60 |127 |- |BP |40 |60 |- |Shell |40 |72 |- |Total |34 |47 |- |Ameren |30 |56 |- |Xcel Energy |20 |54 |- |Google |13 |.04 |- |Disney |10-20 |.9 |- |ConocoPhillips |8-46 |24 |- |Microsoft |6 |.05 |} '''Timeline for implementing social cost of carbon'''
The US Environmental Protection Agency has recently removed their page regarding the social cost of carbon since the new Trump administration has been installed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/29/politics/epa-climate-change-website/index.html|title=EPA removes climate change information from website|last=CNN|first=Rene Marsh|website=CNN|access-date=2017-05-01}}</ref> EPA Director Scott Pruitt's skepticism towards human contributions to climate change has led to a decreased emphasis towards advancing climate change policies. Several administrative advisers have stated that the social cost should be reduced to zero (currently at $36 per ton of carbon dioxide). A possible reduction or elimination of the social carbon cost would lead to the overhaul of dozens of climate regulations established in previous administrations.
'''Colorado'''
In November 2006, voters in [[Boulder, Colorado]] passed what is said to be the first municipal carbon tax. It is a tax on electricity consumption (utility bills) with deductions for using electricity from renewable sources (primarily Xcel's WindSource program). The goal is to reduce carbon emissions to those outlined in the Kyoto Protocol; specifically to reduce their emissions by 7% below 1990 levels by 2012.<ref name="bouldercolorado.gov">Climate Action Plan Tax, City of Boulder, Colorado {{cite web|url=http://www.bouldercolorado.gov/index.php?option%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D7698%26Itemid%3D2844 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110227063524/http://www.bouldercolorado.gov/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=7698&Itemid=2844 |archivedate=2011-02-27 |df= }} June 30, 2010 accessed Aug 5, 2010</ref> Tax revenues are collected by [[Xcel Energy]] and are directed to the city's Office of Environmental Affairs to fund programs to reduce community-wide [[greenhouse gas emissions]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/18/us/18carbon.html|title=City Approves 'Carbon Tax' in Effort to Reduce Gas Emissions|last=Kelley|first=Katie|date=2006-11-18|accessdate=2010-01-28|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>
Boulder's Climate Action Plan (CAP) tax is expected to raise $1.6 million in 2010. The tax was increased to a maximum allowable rate by voters in 2009 to meet CAP goals. Currently the tax is set at $0.0049 /kWh for residential users (ave. $21 per year), $0.0009 /kWh for commercial (ave. $94 per year), and $0.0003 /kWh for industrial (ave. $9,600 per year). The revenues from the tax are expected to decrease over time as businesses and residents reduce their energy use and begin to use more solar and wind power. The tax was renewed by voters on November 6, 2012.<ref name="bouldercolorado.gov"/>
As of 2015, the Boulder carbon tax is estimated to reduce carbon output by over 100,000 tons per year, and allows the city to collect $1.8 million in revenue that is interjected back into the city. Those funds are infused back into the community by providing bike lanes, energy efficient solutions, rebates for business and homeowners to further invest in green energy, and community based programs to further still bring awareness to the movement <ref>{{cite web|url=https://insideclimatenews.org/news/02112015/boulder-taxed-its-way-climate-friendlier-future|title=How Boulder Taxed its Way to a Climate-Friendlier Future|publisher=}}</ref> The tax is Boulder's way of initiating a future global movement. Because of Boulder's progressiveness and willingness to adapt, this was a fantastic opportunity to trail-run this type of program. It leverages all forms of individual - residential, commercial, and industrial. This results in a low surcharge that has been generally well received. The average household pays just US$21 towards the tax each year, while the average business pays just $94 per year.<ref>https://www.smartgrowthamerica.org/app/legacy/documents/Boulder-Carbon-Tax.pdf</ref> The success of the program has provided a stable and efficient means of carbon tax implementation and enforcement that shows its long-term sustainability in all U.S. markets.
'''California''' {{Clear}} In May 2008, the [[Bay Area Air Quality Management District]], which covers nine counties in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], passed a carbon tax on businesses of 4.4 cents per ton of CO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>[http://articles.sfgate.com/2008-05-22/news/17155215_1_carbon-dioxide-greenhouse-gas-emissions Air quality board to fine Bay Area polluters] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315010627/http://articles.sfgate.com/2008-05-22/news/17155215_1_carbon-dioxide-greenhouse-gas-emissions |date=2011-03-15 }}, San Francisco Chronicle, May 22, 2008</ref>
In 2006, the state of California, passed AB-32 ([[Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006]]), which requires California to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. To implement AB-32, the California Air Resources Board proposed a carbon tax, but has yet to reach agreement with the [[Western States Petroleum Association]] which represents the refineries in the state. The WSPA holds that AB-32 only allows a carbon tax to cover administrative costs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.carbonshare.org/californiaAB32.html |title=California and AB32 |website=www.carbonshare.org |accessdate=August 8, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501072422/http://www.carbonshare.org/californiaAB32.html |archive-date=2011-05-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
<span class="s1">'''Maryland'''</span> {{Clear}} In May 2010, [[Montgomery County, Maryland]] passed the nation's first county-level carbon tax.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://itsgettinghotinhere.org/2010/05/19/breaking-news-montgomery-county-passes-nation%E2%80%99s-first-carbon-tax/ |title=Natural Sciences Repository Index 130 |publisher=Itsgettinghotinhere.org |date= |accessdate=2016-08-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018113523/http://itsgettinghotinhere.org/2010/05/19/breaking-news-montgomery-county-passes-nation%e2%80%99s-first-carbon-tax/ |archive-date=2014-10-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The legislation required payments of $5 per ton of CO<sub>2</sub> emitted from any stationary source emitting more than a million tons of carbon dioxide during a calendar year.<ref name="solveclimate.com">{{cite web|url=http://solveclimate.com/blog/20100525/maryland-county-carbon-tax-law-could-set-example-rest-country |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717055202/http://solveclimate.com/blog/20100525/maryland-county-carbon-tax-law-could-set-example-rest-country |archivedate=2010-07-17 |df= }}</ref> There is only one source of emissions fitting the criteria laid out by the council, an 850 megawatt coal-fired power plant owned by [[Mirant Corporation]]. The tax was expected to raise between $10 million and $15 million for the county, which faced a nearly $1 billion budget gap.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/local/Montgomery-poised-to-tax-carbon-to-fight-global-warming-94204419.html |title=Archive Template |publisher=Washingtonexaminer.com |date=2013-06-13 |accessdate=2016-08-24 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The law provided for half of revenue to go toward creating a low interest loan plan for county residents to invest in residential energy efficiency upgrades.<ref name="solveclimate.com"/> The County's energy supplier buys its energy at auction, so Mirant would have to sell its energy at market value, which meant no discernible increase in energy costs would be felt by the county's residents. In June 2010, the Mirant Corporation sued the county to stop the tax.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/local/Billion-dollar-power-company-sues-Montgomery-over-carbon-tax-95657154.html |title=Archive Template |publisher=Washingtonexaminer.com |date=2013-06-13 |accessdate=2016-08-24 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In June 2011 the Federal Court of Appeals ruled that the tax was a fee imposed "for regulatory or punitive purposes" rather than a tax, and therefore could be challenged in court.<ref>http://www.ca4.uscourts.gov/Opinions/Published/101882.P.pdf</ref> The County Council repealed the fee in July 2012.<ref>http://www.montgomerycountymd.gov/council/resources/files/res/2012/20120710_17-484.pdf</ref>
'''Washington''' {{Clear}} In 2016, a group of climate activists put [[Washington Initiative 732|an initiative]] for a revenue-neutral carbon tax on the [[Washington elections, 2016|November ballot]] in [[Washington (state)|Washington State]]. If approved by voters, it would have imposed a tax on carbon dioxide emissions and used that revenue to decrease the state's [[sales tax]], the business tax, and expand the state's version of the [[earned income tax credit]] for low-income workers.
== Harmonized carbon taxes == Cooper (1998, 2001)<ref name=gupta/> has been a leading proponent of a harmonized carbon tax (a tax where the country setting the tax keeps all the revenues). Under his proposals, all participating nations would be subject to a tax at a common rate, thus achieving cost-effectiveness. A number of problems have been suggested with Cooper's proposals: * One criticism is of the fairness of having developing countries being subject to the same tax rates as developed countries, given their relative level of welfare and responsibility for the climate problem. * It has been asked what incentive developed countries would have to adopt a tax. * It is possible that governments would attempt to neutralize the effects of the tax on certain economic sectors. * Given the presence of existing tax distortions, it might not be politically feasible to implement a uniform tax rate.
== Support == Former US Vice President [[Al Gore]] strongly backed a carbon tax in his book, ''[[Earth in the Balance]]''. In 2000, when Gore ran for president, one commentator labeled Gore's carbon tax proposal a "[[central planning]] solution" harking back to "the [[New Deal]] politics of [[Al Gore, Sr.|his father]]."<ref>Noah, Timothy (Nov. 9, 2006). [http://www.slate.com/id/2153390/nav/tap2/ The GOP Triangulates]. ''Slate''.</ref>
[[Greg Mankiw]], head of the Council of Economic Advisers under the George W. Bush administration, economic adviser to Mitt Romney for his 2012 presidential campaign and economics professor at Harvard University since 1985, has been advocating for increased carbon/oil taxation since at least 1999.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20010902083125/http://post.economics.harvard.edu/faculty/mankiw/columns/may99.html Gas Tax Now! First Principles], [[Greg Mankiw]], ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'', May 24, 1999.</ref> In 2006, he founded the [[Pigou Club]] of economists advocating for [[Pigovian tax]]es, a carbon tax chiefly among them. In the club's manifesto, he writes that "[h]igher gasoline taxes, perhaps as part of a broader carbon tax, would be the most direct and least invasive policy to address environmental concerns."<ref>[http://gregmankiw.blogspot.co.uk/2006/10/pigou-club-manifesto.html The Pigou Club Manifesto], Greg Mankiw, October 20, 2006.</ref>
In 1979, economist [[Milton Friedman]] expressed support for the idea of a carbon tax in an interview on ''[[The Phil Donahue Show]]'', saying "...the best way to [deal with pollution] is to impose a tax on the cost of the pollutants emitted by a car and make an incentive for car manufacturers and for consumers to keep down the amount of pollution."<ref>{{cite news|last1=McMahon|first1=Jeff|title=What Would Milton Friedman Do About Climate Change? Tax Carbon|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffmcmahon/2014/10/12/what-would-milton-friedman-do-about-climate-change-tax-carbon/#48e351714573|publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=October 12, 2014|accessdate=March 20, 2016}}</ref>
In 2001, environmental scientist [[Lester Brown]], founder of the [[Worldwatch Institute]] and founder and president of the [[Earth Policy Institute]], outlined a detailed "tax shifting" structure which would not lead to an overall higher tax level: "It means reducing income taxes and offsetting them with taxes on environmentally destructive activities such as carbon emissions, the generation of toxic waste, the use of virgin raw materials, the use of non-refillable beverage containers, mercury emissions, the generation of garbage, the use of pesticides, and the use of throwaway products... activities that should be discouraged by taxing.""<ref>Brown, Lester. ''Eco-Economy: Building an Economy for the Earth'', [http://www.earth-policy.org/books/eco/eech11_ss3 Chapter 11. Tools for Restructuring the Economy: Tax Shifting], Earth Policy Institute (2001)</ref> Brown subsequently added that such a tax shift would amount to an "[[honest market]]," explaining, "The key to restructuring the economy is the creation of an honest market, one that tells the ecological truth."<ref>Brown, Lester. ''Plan B: Rescuing a Planet Under Stress and a Civilization in Trouble'', [http://www.earth-policy.org/books/pb/pbch11_ss4 Chapter 11. Plan B: Rising to the Challenge: Creating an Honest Market], Earth Policy Institute (2003)</ref> In 2011 he estimated the cost of such a tax shift, including the effects of better technology, the use of renewables and "updating the concept of national security."<ref>Brown, Lester. [http://www.earth-policy.org/books/wote/wotepreface2 ''World on the Edge: How to Prevent Environmental and Economic Collapse''], Earth Policy Institute (2011), Preface to Part 3</ref>
Former US [[Federal Reserve]] chairman [[Paul Volcker]] suggested (February 6, 2007) that "it would be wiser to impose a tax on oil, for example, than to wait for the market to drive up oil prices."{{Clarify|date=April 2010|reason=is he in support of a carbon tax?}}<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/02/06/news/FIN-GEN-Egypt-Volcker-Global-Warming.php |title=Economist Paul Volcker says steps to curb global warming would not devastate an economy |date=2007-02-06 |agency=Associated Press |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210011059/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/02/06/news/FIN-GEN-Egypt-Volcker-Global-Warming.php |archivedate=2009-02-10 |accessdate= 2008-04-15}}</ref>
NASA climatologist [[James E. Hansen]] has argued in support of a carbon tax.<ref name="obama"/><ref name="bone"/><ref name="Randerson"/><ref name="truth"/><ref name="kloor"/>
Commencing in North America, the nonprofit [[Citizens Climate Lobby]] has been advocating for carbon tax legislation (specifically a progressive [[fee and dividend]] model with revenue returned to citizens in the form of a check or rebate). The organization has about 165 chapters in the United States, Canada, and several other countries including Bangladesh and Sweden.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://newsok.com/climate-group-forming-in-oklahoma-city/article/3736459?custom_click=pod_headline_national-finance-news |title=Climate group forming in Oklahoma City |date=2012-12-11 |agency=The Oklahoman |accessdate= 2012-12-20}}</ref>
Former United States Congressional Representative [[Bob Inglis]] (R-South Carolina) heads the [[Energy and Enterprise Initiative]] at [[George Mason University]] which is making the conservative case for climate legislation through support for a carbon tax.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://energyandenterprise.com/ |title=Energy and Enterprise Initiative |accessdate= 2012-12-20}}</ref>

In 2015, BG Group, BP, Eni, Royal Dutch Shell, Statoil and Total sent an open letter to the [[UNFCCC]] calling for the implementation of carbon pricing and eventually link it all up into a global system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.unfccc.int/unfccc-newsroom/major-oil-companies-letter-to-un/|title=Six Oil Majors Say: We Will Act Faster with Stronger Carbon Pricing Open Letter to UN and Governments|first=|last=unfccc.com|publisher=|access-date=2018-12-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330124154/http://newsroom.unfccc.int/unfccc-newsroom/major-oil-companies-letter-to-un|archive-date=2018-03-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
[[Monica Prasad]], a Northwestern University sociologist, wrote about Denmark's carbon tax in ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 2008.<ref name="Prasad2008">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/25/opinion/25prasad.html|title=On Carbon, Tax and Don't Spend|date=2008-03-25|work=The New York Times|author=Monica Prasad|accessdate=2010-08-04}}</ref> In her view, the Danish carbon tax served as an example of how to reduce emissions in the US. Prasad argued, however, that a critical component for Denmark's success in reducing carbon emissions from 1990–2005 was that the tax revenues from the carbon tax were dedicated to subsidies for firms to use for alternative, environmentally cleaner sources of energy.
Economist [[Laura D'Andrea Tyson]] wrote in June 2013: "The beauty of a carbon tax is its market-based simplicity. Economists since Adam Smith have insisted that prices are by far the most efficient way to guide the decisions of producers and consumers. Carbon emissions have an "unpriced" societal cost in terms of their deleterious effects on the earth's climate. A tax on carbon would reflect these costs and send a powerful [[price signal]] that would discourage carbon emissions." She listed several prominent economists and political figures that have supported carbon taxes.<ref name="TysonNYT1">{{cite news | last = Tyson |first = Laura |title=The Myriad Benefits of a Carbon Tax|url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/06/28/the-myriad-benefits-of-a-carbon-tax/#more-164986|accessdate=June 28, 2013|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 28, 2013}}</ref>
[[Carbon Tax Now]] is an online petition for citizens from around the globe to show support for implementing a carbon tax in their country of citizenship.<ref name="Carbon-Tax-Now"> {{cite web |url=http://www.carbontaxnow.org/ |title=Carbon Tax Now |access-date=14 April 2016}}</ref>
== Stance by the Sierra Club == In 2016 in [[Washington state]], the [[Sierra Club]], the Washington Environmental Council, Climate Solutions, and the Alliance for Jobs and Clean Energy opposed a proposed tax of $25 per tonne on fossil fuels arguing that the enactment would undermine state finances.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wecprotects.org/wec-position-732/|title=WEC Statement on I-732 |work=Washington Environmental Council|date= October 14, 2016}}</ref>
In 2018, they instead supported a carbon tax of $15 per tonne of carbon in that state, along with many other environmental groups, in part because the proceeds would fund projects that would steer the state away from fossil fuels.<ref>{{cite news |title=Best Way to Fight Climate Change? Put an Honest Price on Carbon |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/29/opinion/climate-change-carbon-price.html |accessdate=31 October 2018 |publisher=NY Times |date=29 October 2018}}</ref>
==Carbon taxes compared to cap-and-trade== {{See also| Cap-and-trade}}
An alternative government policy to a carbon tax is a cap on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Emission levels of GHGs are capped and permits to pollute are freely allocated (called "grandfathering") or auctioned to polluters. Auctioning permits has significant economic advantages over grandfathering. In particular, auctioning raises revenues that can be used to reduce distortionary taxes and improve overall efficiency.<ref name=smith>{{cite web|date=June 11, 2008|title=Environmentally Related Taxes and Tradable Permit Systems in Practice|publisher=[[OECD]], Environment Directorate, [[Centre for Tax Policy and Administration]]|url=http://www.olis.oecd.org/olis/2007doc.nsf/LinkTo/NT00005FF2/$FILE/JT03247683.PDF|author=Smith, S.|accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref> A market may be allowed for these emission permits so that polluters can trade some or all of their permits with others (cap-and-trade). A hybrid instrument of a cap and carbon tax can be made by creating a price-floor and price-ceiling for emission permits.<ref name= hepburn /> A carbon tax can also be implemented concurrently with a cap.<ref name=goldemberg/>
Unlike a cap system with grandfathered permits, a carbon tax raises revenues. If the revenues are used to reduce other distortionary taxes, this can improve the efficiency of the tax. On the other hand, a cap with grandfathered permits can have an efficiency advantage of being applied to all industries. This provides an equal incentive at the [[margin (economics)|margin]] for all polluters to reduce their emissions. This is an advantage over a tax that exempts or has reduced rates for certain sectors.<ref name=smith />
Both carbon taxes and permit systems ([[Cap-and-trade|Cap and Trade]]) aim to reduce the total quantity of carbon emissions by creating a price for emitting {{CO2}} pollution, but they achieve this goal in distinctly separate ways.<ref name="Jacobsen, Mark 2016">Jacobsen, Mark. “Environmental Economics Lecture 6-7.” UCSD Econ 131. Econ 131 Lecture, 20 Oct. 2016, San Diego, UCSD .</ref> While carbon taxes dictate the price that will be paid for each unit of pollution, permit systems set a specific quantity of {{CO2}} that all applicable entities will be held to and divides this total amount into tradable permits.<ref name="Jacobsen, Mark 2016"/> In the absence of uncertainty these two systems will achieve the same effect and result in the efficient market quantity of {{CO2}} and price charged per unit of {{CO2}} emitted.<ref name="Jacobsen, Mark 2016"/><ref name="lse.ac.uk">“Which Is Better: Carbon Tax or Cap-and-Trade?” Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment, London School of Economics, 21 Mar. 2014, www.lse.ac.uk/GranthamInstitute/faqs/which-is-better-carbon-tax-or-cap-and-trade/.</ref> In the case of environmental uncertainty, that is when the environmental damages of each unit of {{CO2}} cannot be accurately calculated, a permit system may be more advantageous in order to limit total quantity and thus potential damages.<ref name="lse.ac.uk"/> In the case of uncertainty regarding the costs of {{CO2}} abatement for firms, a tax is preferable.<ref name="lse.ac.uk"/><ref name="Jacobsen, Mark 2016"/><ref name="c2es.org">“Cap and Trade vs. Taxes.” Center for Climate and Energy Solutions, Center for Climate and Energy Solutions, 24 Oct. 2017, www.c2es.org/document/cap-and-trade-vs-taxes/.</ref> The abatement uncertainty issue was illustrated in 2005 by the first phase of the European Union Emissions Trading System (cap and trade).<ref>“EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS).” Icapcarbonaction.com, International Carbon Action Partnership, 10 Oct. 2017, icapcarbonaction.com/en/?option=com_etsmap&task=export&format=pdf&layout=list&systems[]=43</ref><ref name="Jacobsen, Mark 2016"/><ref name="c2es.org"/> In this program, the initial allocation of permits was too great as the EU did not accurately assess the {{CO2}} reduction capabilities of the various firms it regulated, and thus firms simply reduced their emissions to their allotted quantity without the purchase of any additional permits.<ref name="Jacobsen, Mark 2016"/> This drove the permit prices to nearly zero two years after the program began, crashing the system and commanding reform and permit allocation refinement that would eventually manifest itself in the current European Union Emissions Trading System (Phase 3)<ref name="Jacobsen, Mark 2016"/><ref>“EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS).” Icapcarbonaction.com, International Carbon Action Partnership, 10 Oct. 2017, icapcarbonaction.com/en/?option=com_etsmap&task=export&format=pdf&layout=list&systems[]=43.</ref>

==== Difficulties with taxes ==== According to the [[Carbon Trust]] (2009), a carbon tax suffers from combining a set price for carbon along with a transfer of revenue from industry to government.<ref name=carbont /> This, it is argued, guarantees that the tax will not be set at the appropriate level, but will instead be determined by the politics of large-scale revenue transfers. With a cap, however, the revenues from emission allowances can be separately negotiated with industry.
Another issue with taxes is whether the emissions reductions they bring about actually exist – that is, the "additionality" of emissions reductions attributable solely to the taxes (Carbon Trust, 2009). Additionality usually requires a comparison of observed emission reductions against an estimate of the emission reductions that would have taken place without the presence of the tax (the emissions "baseline"). The additionality of a carbon tax, in this sense, is difficult to establish because other policies usually will also have impacts on levels of emissions, e.g., subsidies and regulations. (As a case in point, greenhouse gas emissions from British Columbia had fallen 4.5% between 2007 and 2010 following imposition of its carbon tax. However, it is estimated by the government that most of this decrease is, in fact, attributable to an economic recession.<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/economy-plays-key-role-in-bc-meeting-greenhouse-gas-targets/article4375930/ "Economy plays key role in B.C. meeting greenhouse gas targets"], June 28, 2012</ref>) There are about US$550 billion in [[fossil fuel subsidies]] annually worldwide.<ref name=subsidies>IEA (June 16, 2010) [http://www.oecd.org/env/45575666.pdf Analysis of the Scope of Energy Subsidies and Suggestions for the G-20 Initiative] Retrieved 2014-06-29.</ref>
== Distributional impacts == In most instances, firms pass the costs of a carbon price onto consumers. Studies typically find that poor consumers spend a greater proportion of their income on energy-intensive goods and fuel, and cost increases in energy tend to impact the poor worse than the rich.<ref>{{cite web|year=2008|title=Tackling Carbon: How to price carbon for climate policy|author=Neuhoff, K.|publisher=Electricity Policy Research Group|url=http://www.eprg.group.cam.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/tackling-carbon_final_3009082.pdf|accessdate=August 30, 2009}}</ref> Therefore, if the revenue from a carbon tax is retained by the government, a price on carbon is expected to be regressive, similar to any policy that increases the cost of fuels and energy.
A study by Resources for the Future (2014) examined the regressive nature of a carbon tax evaluating three different options for the use of a revenue neutral carbon tax. The study concluded that distributing the fee back to the public as a lump sum payment eliminates the regressive nature of the carbon tax, where people in the lower 60% of income brackets will, on average, perceive a positive impact on their household welfare.<ref>{{cite web|year=2014 |title=The Initial Incidence of a Carbon Tax across Income Groups|author1=Roberton C. Williams III |author2=Hal Gordon |author3=Dallas Burtraw |author4=Jared C. Carbone |author5=Richard D. Morgenstern |publisher=Resources for the Future|url=http://www.rff.org/research/publications/initial-incidence-carbon-tax-across-income-groups|accessdate=January 6, 2016}}</ref>
Studies by Metcalf ''et al.'' (2008) and Metcalf (2009) consider the possible distributional impacts of carbon taxes in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|date=June 2009|author=Burtraw, D.|title=The Incidence of U.S. Climate Policy: Alternative Uses of Revenues from a Cap-and-Trade Auction|publisher=Resources for the Future|url=http://www.rff.org/RFF/Documents/RFF-DP-09-17-REV.pdf|accessdate=September 2, 2009|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The 2008 study considers three recent tax bills introduced to the [[US Congress]]. The taxes themselves are highly [[regressive tax|regressive]], but when revenues from the tax are returned lump-sum, the taxes become [[progressive tax|progressive]]. The 2009 study looks at a carbon tax combined with a reduction in [[payroll tax]]es. It is found that this combination can be distributionally neutral. With an adjustment in [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security payments]] for the lowest-income households, the carbon tax policy can be made progressive.
A study by [[Paul Ekins|Ekins]] and Dresner (2004) considers the distributional impact in the UK of introducing a carbon tax and increasing fuel duty.<ref>{{cite web |author1 = Ekins, P. |author2 = S. Dresner |year = 2004 |url = http://www.jrf.org.uk/node/1231 |title = Green taxes and charges: Reducing their impact on low-income households |publisher = [[Joseph Rowntree Foundation]] |accessdate = September 4, 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090401011121/http://www.jrf.org.uk/node/1231 |archivedate = April 1, 2009 |df = }}</ref> It is found that a carbon tax can be made progressive, but that the tax would make those currently worst affected by fuel poverty more badly off. Of the policy options looked at for transport, the most effective in compensating low-income motorists is found to be an increase in fuel duties and the abolishment of [[vehicle excise duty]].
== Footnotes == Bashmakov ''et al.'' (2001) refer to emissions taxes.<ref name="association of emissions taxes with trade etc"/> Carbon taxes are not identical to emissions taxes, but they can be designed to be a close approximation.<ref name="bashmakov collection point and tax base"/>

Recurring topics include homosexuality, atheism, Hollywood, and other purported threats to American culture.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.theatlanticwire.com/opinions/view/opinion/Satirical-Christian-Site-Hoodwinks-the-Huffington-Post-4766 |title= Satirical Christian Site Hoodwinks the Huffington Post |author=John Hudson |date=August 19, 2010 |work=The Atlantic Wire}}</ref><ref name=AtlanticMaddow>{{cite news |url= http://www.theatlanticwire.com/opinions/view/opinion/Rachel-Maddow-and-NBC-Struggle-With-Satire-6795 |title=Rachel Maddow and NBC Struggle With Satire |author=John Hudson |date=February 1, 2011 |work=The Atlantic Wire}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/08/18/signs-your-husband-is-gay_n_687160.html |title=9 Signs Your Husband Is GAY, According To ChristWire.org (PHOTOS) |work=Huffington Post |author= Katla McGlynn |date=August 18, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.smh.com.au/national/the-diary/line-of-inquiry-crosses-a-line-20100818-12f98.html |title=Line of inquiry crosses a line |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=August 19, 2010}}</ref>
Like similar satirical websites, Christwire's stories have sometimes been erroneously taken at face value.<ref name=AtlanticMaddow/>
==Topekasnews== Due to the wide public attention at the name Christwire, the site also runs topekasnews.com.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://christwire.org/2012/09/heathen-topekasnews-liberals-detest-reaganomics/|title=Heathen TopekasNews Liberals Detest Reaganomics|work=ChristWire}}</ref><ref name="topekasnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://topekasnews.com/christians-review-scooby-doo-the-first-atheist-brainwashing-cartoon/|title=Christians Review, "Scooby Doo, The First Atheist Brainwashing Cartoon" - Topekas News|work=topekasnews.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://christwire.org/2013/06/scooby-doo-the-first-atheist-brainwashing-cartoon-reviewed/|title=Scooby Doo, The First Atheist Brainwashing Cartoon Reviewed|work=ChristWire}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patheos.com/blogs/friendlyatheist/2013/12/05/the-popular-story-of-the-kansas-city-prayer-booths-is-false-but-the-brilliant-artist-behind-the-booth-is-genuine/|title=The Popular Story of the Kansas City Prayer Booths Is False, But the Brilliant Artist Behind the Booth is Genuine|work=Friendly Atheist}}</ref><ref>[http://topekasnews.com/marijuana-cures-republican-pastor-stupidity/ Marijuana Cures Republican Pastor of Stupidity] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626105448/http://topekasnews.com/marijuana-cures-republican-pastor-stupidity/ |date=2015-06-26 }}</ref>

with their own coat:''' || [[Au (Munich)|Au]], [[Aubing]], [[Feldmoching]], [[Milbertshofen]], [[Obermenzing]], [[Pasing]], [[Schwabing]], [[Untermenzing]] |} The '''coat of arms of Munich''' ''('''Münchner Wappen''')'' depicts a young monk dressed in black holding a red book. It has existed in a similar form since the 13th century, though at certain points in its history it has not depicted the central figure of the monk at all. As the German name for [[Munich]], München, means ''of Monks'', the [[monk]] in this case is a self-explanatory symbol ([[canting arms]]) who represents the city of Munich. Appearing on a document of May 28, 1239, the oldest seal of Munich has a picture of a monk wearing an open hood. While all seal impressions show the monk with the book in one hand and three outstretched fingers in the other, the monk has varied slightly, appearing in profile, then later full-faced and bare-headed. By the 19th century the figure was portrayed as youthful and became known as the [[Münchner Kindl]] or ''Munich Child''. The [[coat of arms]] in its current form was created in 1957 and is still an important symbol of the [[Bavaria]]n state capital. == The Monk == [[Image:München kleines stadtsiegel 1304.png|thumb|left|150px|Small seal, 1304]] As the German name for Munich, i.e. München, means ''"of Monks"'',{{cite news|url=http://www.hdbg.de/gemeinden2/bayerns-gemeinden_detail.php?gkz=9162000 |title=Bayerns Gemeinden Detailansicht |publisher=Haus der Bayerischen Geschichte |language=German |accessdate=2008-07-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091220040636/http://www.hdbg.de/gemeinden2/bayerns-gemeinden_detail.php?gkz=9162000 |archivedate=December 20, 2009 }} the [[monk]] in this case is a self-explanatory symbol who represents the city of Munich. The figure is portrayed wearing a golden trimmed black [[cowl]] with a black hood and red shoes. The right hand is raised and the left carries a red book. The open right hand of the monk is interpreted as an oath-making gesture, or a blessing gesture in Christian tradition. The red book in the left hand refers to the oath book of the city (in accordance with the gesture of the right hand), or the municipal law book which is bounded in red and has been handed down since 1365. Another interpretation is that it is a gospel book. When the Munich town administration developed a constitution of its council, a seal was necessary for the purposes of asserting the authenticity of town-council documents. Appearing on a document of May 28, 1239, the oldest seal of Munich has a picture of a monk wearing an open hood.{{cite news|url=http://www.steincollectors.org/library/articles/MKindl/MKindl.htm|title=History of the Munich Child|last=Lowenstein|first=Jack|date=September 1968|publisher=steincollectors.org|accessdate=2008-07-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516224346/http://steincollectors.org/library/articles/MKindl/MKindl.htm|archivedate=2008-05-16|df=}} While all seal impressions show the monk with the book in one hand and three outstretched fingers in the other, the monk has varied slightly, appearing in profile, then later full-faced and bare-headed. The monk as a sole heraldic figure can be found on a seal dating from the year 1304, and on flags of the city since the middle of the 14th century.{{cite news|url=http://www.ngw.nl/int/dld/m/munchen.htm|title=Wappen von MÜNCHEN|publisher=ngw.nl|accessdate=2008-07-22}} Colourful representations of the town's coat of arms stem from the 15th century. === Münchner Kindl === {{main|Münchner Kindl}} In the course of the few centuries up until the current version of 1957, the coat of arms has undergone some distinctly visible changes. While some 15th-century portrayals already show a child figure instead of the monk, the monk in representations onwards began to lose its serious disposition, with curly hair and a more youthful-looking face. By the 18th century and especially the 19th century, the monk had been minimised into the [[Münchner Kindl]], Bavarian for ''Munich Child'', a reference to the figure first documented in 1727, although it is not clear when it appeared on the coat of arms for the first time or who coined the term. The transformation was brought about by artists such as sculptors and painters as well as copper and seal engravers, as opposed to a legal order. In the second half of the nineteenth century, local artists also supplemented the figure with items such as radishes, pretzels, laurel wreaths and foaming beer steins. The symbol diversely appears in numerous places such as on manhole covers, beer steins and the top of the tower of the town hall.{{cite news|url=http://www.stadtmuseum-online.de/archiv/kindl2.htm|title=Archiv: Das Münchner Kindl - 2|publisher=stadtmuseum-online.de|language=German|accessdate=2008-07-22}} While the symbol as a man through being a monk was previously clear, its gender has become ambiguous since being designated the Kindl. One interpretation is that it is simply genderless, however in the 1920s a female inclination became apparent, and portrayals in person are to this day by young women.{{cite news|url=http://www.stadtmuseum-online.de/archiv/kindl3.htm|title=Archiv: Das Münchner Kindl - 3|publisher=stadtmuseum-online.de|language=German|accessdate=2008-07-22}} == History == The Munich coat of arms is verifiable from seals in 1239 and 1268. These seals show a monk in a gate, above which is in eagle, referring to the Bishop of Freising. The city belonged to him and this was probably derived from his coat of arms. From 1313, the city was in possession of the [[House of Wittelsbach|Wittelsbach]] Dukes and the eagle was replaced with a lion, a symbol of the old Bavarian and Palatine Wittelsbachs since the [[Fiefdom]] of Duke [[Louis I, Duke of Bavaria|Ludwig]] in 1214.{{cite news|url=http://www.bayern.de/Coat-of-Arms-and-Flags-.654.htm|title=Bayerisches Landesportal: Coat of Arms and Flags|publisher=Bayrische Staatsregierung|accessdate=2008-07-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917195644/http://www.bayern.de/Coat-of-Arms-and-Flags-.654.htm|archivedate=2008-09-17|df=}} === Coat of arms after ratification by Max I. Joseph === In 1808, King [[Maximilian I Joseph of Bavaria|Maximilian I Joseph]] granted the city a [[Historicism (art)|historicist]] city emblem depicting a classical portal, atop which the King's crown lies. A golden lion sits in the gate's threshold with a sword in one paw and a shield with the letter "M" in the other. As an [[Enlightened absolutism|enlightened monarch]], Max I. Joseph wanted the city's symbol to show its culture and at the same time dispel the stereotype of the "''Mönchsbarbarei''", or the barbarianism of the monks. However, the township decided against the complete elimination of the historical reference to the monk and thus in 1818 the M was replaced with the previous monk's head design. Image:Wappen München 1808-1818.png|1808–1818 Image:Wappen München 1818-1835.png|1818–1835 === Coat of arms after ratification by Ludwig I === In 1834, [[Ludwig I of Bavaria|King Ludwig I]] granted the city its old coat of arms again in the form of large and small crests. These embodied the small crest seal of 1304 and the large one of 1323. The 1835 coat of arms had a blue background, though this was later corrected to [[argent]] under [[Ludwig II of Bavaria|Ludwig II]] in 1865. The background was rarely changed. One example of its occurrence, however, was when [[Or (heraldry)|or]] was used in the 16th century instead. Image:Wappen München 1835-1865 Klein.png|1835–1865
Small Coat of arms Image:Wappen München 1865 Groß.png|1865–1936
1949–1957
Large Coat of arms Image:Wappen München 1865-1836 - 1949-1957.png|1865–1936
1949–1957
Small Coat of arms === Coat of arms in the Third Reich === From 1936 to 1945, the lion was once again replaced by an eagle, only this time the one of the Nazi party, the ''Reichsadler''. Deemed the ''Hauptstadt der Bewegung'' (Capital of the Movement), Munich was a significant place in terms of the [[Nazism|Nazi ideology]]. The city was home to the [[Nazi Party|NSDAP]] headquarters, the [[Beer Hall Putsch]] and also saw the establishment of [[Dachau concentration camp|Dachau]], the first Nazi concentration camp. Post-war designs were not pursued until 1949. Image:Wappen München 1936-1945.png|1936–1945 === New coat of arms === Both a small and large coat of arms existed from 1949 until 1957 based on representations of them prior to 1936. In 1957 both the large and small city coat of arms were newly arranged by the [[designer]] Eduard Ege. At the same time, the city council set the resolution on the December 17, 1957 that the large one was no longer for official use but only for particular representative purposes. Image:Großes Stadtwappen München.svg|1957 to today,
large coat of arms
used only for special occasions. Image:Muenchen Kleines Stadtwappen.svg|1957 to today,
small coat of arms,
officially used version. ==See also== *[[Coat of arms of Germany]] *[[Coat of arms of Bavaria]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * K. Stadler: ''Deutsche Wappen – Bundesrepublik Deutschland.'' Angelsachsen Verlag 1964–1971. 8th Volume. == External links == {{Commons category|Seals and Coats of arms of Munich}} * [http://www.datenmatrix.de/projekte/hdbg/gemeinden/cgi-local/detail.cgi?gkz=9162000 House of Bavarian History: Coat of Arms and Coat of Arm history] {{De icon}} * [http://www.ngw.nl/int/dld/m/munchen.htm ngw.nl: Coat of arms description] {{En icon}} * [http://www.muenchen.de/Rathaus/stadtverwaltung/stadtwappen.html Information of the state capital Munich's Coat of arms] {{De icon}} {{good article}} [[Category:History of Munich]] [[Category:Government of Munich]] [[Category:Municipal coats of arms in Germany|Munich]] [[Category:Coats of arms with books|Munich]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crosses|Munich]]

The '''Destruction in Art Symposium''' (DIAS) was a gathering of a diverse group of international artists, poets, and scientists to [[London]], from 9–11 September 1966. Included in this number were representatives of the [[Counter-culture|counter-cultural]] underground who were there to speak on the theme of destruction in art.
The Honorary Committee, led by [[Gustav Metzger]], attracted the attention of both the international media and international art community to the symposium.<ref name="TateDIAS">[http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-britain/exhibition/art-60s-was-tomorrow/exhibition-themes/destruction-art-symposium Destruction in Art Symposium], Art & The 60s: This was Tomorrow, Tate Britain, retrieved 2006-08-30.</ref>
==Event== The symposium was held at the [[Africa Centre]] in [[Covent Garden]], London.
==Objectives== A DIAS press release claimed: {{cquote|The main objective of DIAS was to focus attention on the element of destruction in Happenings and other art forms, and to relate this destruction in society.|author=DIAS<ref name="TateDIAS" />}}
==Happenings== Throughout September, [[Happenings]] took place in venues all over London, including Conway Hall.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Miki|title=Yoko Ono at the Destruction In The Art Symposium (DIAS) from "DIAS - Photofeature" by John Prosser in "Art and Artists" October, 1966|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/mickeyono2005/6318888303|website=Flickr|publisher=Flickr|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref><ref name="TateDIAS" />
===The laws of England=== [[John Latham (artist)|John Latham]] constructed three large "Skoob Towers" out of books, which they called "The laws of England", and set fire to them outside of the [[British Museum]].
==Honorary Committee== *[[Mario Amaya]] *[[Roy Ascott]] *[[Enrico Baj]] *[[Bob Cobbing]] *[[Ivor Davies (artist)]] *[[James Haynes]] (known as Jim Haynes) *[[Sylvester Houédard]] *[[Barry Miles]] *[[Frank Popper]] *[[John J. Sharkey]] *[[Wolf Vostell]] *[[Gustav Metzger]] (Honorary Secretary)
==Participants== The following artists were involved in DIAS: *[[Gustav Metzger]] *[[Al Hansen]] *[[Ralph Ortiz]] *[[Wolf Vostell]] *[[John Latham (artist)|John Latham]] *[[Robin Page]] *[[Yoko Ono]] *[[Günter Brus]] *[[Otto Mühl]] *[[Hermann Nitsch]] *[[Peter Weibel]] *[[Juan Hidalgo Codorniu|Juan Hidalgo]] *[[Henri Chopin]]
The following artists are said to have participated in DIAS ''[[wikt:in absentia|in absentia]]'':<ref>[http://www.medienkunstnetz.de/works/dias/ Gustav Metzger DIAS], Media Art Net, retrieved 2006-08-30.</ref>
*[[Ivor Davies (artist)|Ivor Davies]] *[[Pro Diaz]] *[[Fred Hunter]] *[[Barbara Steveni]] *[[Jasia Reichardt]] *[[Werner Schreib]] *[[John Sharkey]] *[[Biff Stevens]] *[[Garry A. Jones]] *[[Christopher A Whittaker]] Photographers: *[[Tom Picton]] *[[John Prosser]] *[[Hanns Sohm]] (collector)
